I was a member of Amnesty International before I came into this place, and I will remain a member long after I leave this place, because I believe firmly in the ideals for which Amnesty fight. We as political activists do not know whether one day we might need the benefit of Amnesty International. So I say: congratulations to Amnesty International for surviving 40 years.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
âI move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) acknowledges that almost one third of all Australian workers are now working more than 50 hours per week;
(2) notes that the French Government has recently legislated for a 35 hour week;
(3) conduct a review of the operation of the French legislation, and its success or otherwise; and
(4) consult widely with the community, the business sector and trade unions, to explore the appropriateness or otherwise of applying similar values to an Australian context.

speech.para: Recent data on work practices in Australian workplaces indicates that a significant proportionâapproximately one thirdâof all Australian workers are now working more than 50 hours a week. Indeed, data outlines that Australia now has the second largest group of workers working 49 hours or more a week of all 20 OECD countries. Further, a recent ACTU survey of almost 7,000 Australian workers found that more than 60 per cent of all overtime worked in Australia is unpaid. This figure translates into Australian workers performing 11.4 million hours of unpaid overtime per weekâthe equivalent of 300,000 full-time, 38-hour-a-week jobs.

In 1999-2000, the total number of hours of overworkâthis includes both paid and unpaid overtimeâreached 1,034 million. As a rough guide, this is equivalent to around 500,000 full-time jobs. At present, 585,000 Australians are officially looking for work. In the finance sector alone, about one million hours of unpaid overtime are worked. This equals 23,000 full-time jobs, which is almost exactly the number of jobs lost in that sector since 1995.

I believe that, at this time in Australia's development, when many people find themselves underemployed or unemployed, Australians working excessive and unpaid hours is unacceptable. Working excessive and unpaid hours creates a variety of negative consequences including: the effects on workers' family lives and health, with subsequent consequences upon community health services and facilities; economic effects on families and communities, including consequences related to welfare and PAYG tax not forwarded to the Commonwealth for hours not paid; and what would seem to be an ever-widening gap in wealth between people at various socioeconomic levels in Australia.

I agree with Greg Combet, the ACTU secretary, when he said recently that reducing the pressure to work unreasonable hours is not only smart but fair. Despite one of the longest periods of economic growth in our history, income inequality in Australia continues to grow. Working families simply are not getting their fair share of the extra productivity that longer and more flexible working hours have delivered for Australian business. I believe that, as parliamentarians, we must work towards the formulation of national policy which will, as far as can appropriately be achieved, see an overall reduction of excessive and unpaid hours being worked by Australian employees and the establishment of dialogue with the ACTU and other interested parties to achieve the same.

The pursuit of decent working conditions is forever an issue in Australian politics. Proper working hours are fundamental to a good workplace. Presently these are under serious threat. In France, the socialist government has implemented a 35-hour working week to help reduce unemployment and improve workers' quality of life. Employees can actually work up to 44 hours a week on overtime. It is argued that a 35-hour working week would give workers a better quality of life and help cut unemployment by creating more jobs. The pledge by the Prime Minister of France was incredibly popular amongst working people. The 35-hour week was central to the high standing of the French government among workers and typifies the swing to the left in French politics in recent years. That swing dates from December 1995 when massive public sector strikes paralysed the nation. As a consequence of the strikes, the Socialist Party moved to the left, and the Greens and the Communist Party won increasing support. The leftward shift in the whole of French society saw the plural left coalition win government in 1997.

There are five main provisions of the French law. The law confirms a new, legal working week of 35 hours, spells out the rules governing overtime, sets forth new arrangements for organising work hours, introduces new tax breaks on employer contributions, and creates a wage guarantee system for minimum wage employees. As Adele Horin reported in the Sydney Morning Herald in May:

quote.para: The doomsayers predicted the worst. But more than a year after France legislated a 35-hour week, the economy is flourishing, unemployment is falling, consumer confidence has hit a historic high and most French say their lifestyle has improved.
People are spending more time at the gym and more time with their kids; they dine out more often, take more holidays and spend extra leisure hours sprucing up their homes.

The Reuters news agency reported (in May) that 59 per cent of workers polled felt their daily life had improved as a result of the shorter hours. The happiest workers were those who regularly took a half-day or full day off work, or extra holidays. The 35-hour week was propelling the French into stores, cinemas and travel agents.

Britain's The Daily Telegraph reported earlier this year that subscriptions to France's leading gym chain had soared, the Paris traffic was thinner on some weekdays and polls showed `workers were happier than at any time in recent memory'.

speech.para: The motion also refers to the application of shorter working hours to an Australian context. In 1999, the ACTU launched a national health and safety campaign titled `Reasonable hours are safer hours'. Longer working hours have been linked to a higher risk of heart disease, and can worsen existing medical problems, including diabetes, epilepsy, hypertension, asthma and digestive problems. Fatigue is a growing health and safety concern. It is estimated that fatigue may be a contributing factor in up to 40 per cent of accidents.

The ACTU survey of occupational health and safety delegates representing more that 800 workplaces around Australia revealed that 78 per cent of respondents frequently or sometimes work more than five days in a row; one in four people say their ability to take rest and meal breaks at work has decreased; 78 per cent complain of fatigue either frequently or sometimes; 42 per cent report that working hours contribute to accidents, with nearly one in seven of them specifying car accidents or near misses; 45 per cent say their health has suffered because of their working hours; and 56 per cent of those surveyed indicated that shiftwork systems operate in their workplaces; but less than one-quarter expressed a preference for shiftwork.

Last week the ACTU filed a test case in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which set out to create new award guidelines for reasonable working hours. In this test case the ACTU seeks to establish new award guidelines that ensure hours of work are not unreasonable. Factors such as employee safety, family responsibility, workload and the total number of hours worked over an extended period will be considered in determining reasonable hours of work. All workers and, in particular, working women will be major beneficiaries if unions are successful in their bid to have reasonable working hours guidelines introduced into Australian workplace awards. If employers are prohibited from requiring employees to work unreasonable hours, it will be of significant benefit to working men and women struggling to balance the demands of work and family.

During the process of filing the test case, Sharan Burrow, ACTU president, said it was time for unions, the government and employers to work together to find practical solutions that would bring balance to the lives of working families. Employers have a legal duty of care to ensure a healthy and safe workplace and safe systems of work. Although employers have been trying every way possible to frustrate the case being heard, reasonable hours of work are essential to this. Governments need to act to safeguard the health and safety of citizens by creating an industrial relations environment where health and safety are not put at risk through dangerous working hours, and to re-establish community standards regarding working hours and workloads, based on health and safety principles.

As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, all of the great initiatives in improving the working conditions and the conditions of life of working people and their families have been fought for and achieved by the combined efforts of the industrial and political arms of the great labour movement. Australia led the world with the eight-hour day. The conservatives have always opposed these innovations. According to them, the economy could never afford higher wages or a shorter working week. On the achievement of every innovation, the conservatives have been proven wrong. It is absurd for anyone to claim that with the great improvements in technology and the great increases in labour productivity the time has not arrived when the working people of this nation can be rewarded with a shorter working week. We know that a shorter working week will eventually be realised. It may be realised in our working lives or in our children's working lives, but we should grasp the nettle and do it now. Workers and their families would applaud us.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âI rise to speak to the motion moved by the member for Charlton regarding a reduction in the number of working hours as per the recent French legislation reducing the number of working hours from 39 hours to 35 hours per week. The first point of this motion makes a claim that around 33 per cent of all Australian workers work more than 50 hours per week. I dispute this claim and question the validity of this information, since `all Australian workers' include part-time, casual and seasonal workers. Statistics actually place 25 per cent of the Australian work force as working no more than 45 hours a week, so I would like to know to whom those figures were attributed.

speech.para: The ACTU will quote from a recent OECD report into the working hours of member countries that actually places Australia as second, behind the US, for the greatest number of average weekly working hours. However, closer inspection of the OECD report actually produces a different treatment of the statistics. The report itself notes that the results should not be used to weigh country against country on the issue of the number of hours worked, as the sources of information were different. In other words, you cannot draw the inference taken by the ACTU and the opposition because the data obtained was not subject to the same controls.

For some Australian businesses and sectors longer working hours is an issue; however, it is not an issue in every sector or industry in Australia. Consequently, any use of the French legislation as an ideal should be carefully considered in the light of regulatory frameworks in the French workplace being very different from those in the Australian workplace. The French legislation that reduces the number of working hours from 39 to 35 is based on the premise that the reduction in working time contributes to an improvement in the quality of life for employees, particularly for part-time employees, the majority of whom are women.

Reductions in working hours have also been seen as a measure to combat unemployment through work sharing arrangements. The notion of work sharing has been a very popular one amongst the trade union movement and is the premise of this French legislation called the Aubry law, after the Minister for Employment and Solidarity, Martine Aubry. It is interesting to note that in Australia the idea of work sharing or job sharing as part of a redistribution of working hours was abruptly dismissed by the federal Labor government during the preparation of the green and white papers on unemployment policy during the early 1990s. I am a great advocate of job sharing and have been since the days I worked in an employment agency. I believe that you should give women the choice either to work in a job share situation or to work full time, because our life cycles change according to where we are at our time in life.

Under the Howard government's changes to the workplace relations system, workers and employers have the opportunity to negotiate their own workplace agreements. This particular process encourages flexibility in the workplace, and the great winners of this have been women. They have been able to organise more flexible work hours and conditions. Today the participation rate of women in the work force stands as one of the highest, at 55 per cent. Between March 1996 and April 2001, some 448,400 additional jobs in the female labour market were created under the Howard government, including 184,500 full-time jobs. Only 80,400 full-time jobs were created under Labor between July 1990 and March 1996.

The implementation of the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Act 1999 ensures equal opportunity outcomes for women by allowing employers to focus on actions and achievements. One of the principal objects of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 was to assist employees to balance their work and family responsibilities. Under this act the Howard government has taken action to remove arbitrary restrictions on part-time employment and encourage increased award provisions for part-time employment.

In addition, there has been an overall increase in the number of family friendly provisions in collective agreements, with approximately 76 per cent of agreements in 1999 containing at least one family friendly measure, including flexible hours provisions. The French legislation to reduce the statutory number of actual work hours to 35 hours came into effect on 1 January 2000 for companies employing more than 20 people and will come into effect on 1 January 2002 for companies employing 20 or fewer employees. The figure of 35 hours a week effectively defines the threshold beyond which overtime is calculated.

One of the most interesting components of this legislation is that it does not reduce the statutory minimum wage of the workerâ called the SMIC in Franceâeven though the actual number of hours has been reduced from 39 to 35 per week. The Aubry law provides that companies pay a top-up wage differential, which is effectively equal to 11.4 per cent, to ensure that the 35 hours work by SMIC recipients will be paid the same as under the 39 hours per week agreement. State subsidies have been granted to compensate companies for their extra expenditure, and in France these are in the form of a reduction in social security contributions. I do not see what the sense of that is.

The law also institutes a 10 per cent tax on the first four hours of overtime worked by employees who have not had their hours reduced. This money would contribute to a fund for financing the reduction of working time and, in addition, a 15 per cent premium would be paid to employees. From a company perspective, overtime will continue to cost a company 25 per cent more than normal hours. This would reflect little change if the total number of hours worked per employee remained static. However, the reduction in total hours worked would incur additional overtime costs to a business and have a considerable impact on the cash flow of small to medium sized enterprises. Although these measures provide monetary benefits to employees, Alexandre Bilous in 1998 noted that they would have a negative effect on the state budget.

Another issue of the Aubry law is the requirement of a signature on a company agreement by a mandated employee. In a company where there is no trade union delegate or work force delegate performing the function of a union delegate, the law requires that a relevant company agreement may be signed by an employee expressly mandated to do so by a nationally representative trade union. In France this aspect of the law raises considerable concern for small to medium sized enterprises because trade unions are currently absent from the small to medium sized enterprise sector. It is estimated that 65 per cent of French companies with 50 to 90 employees and 45 per cent of those with 100 to 199 employees have no trade union delegate. The law effectively provides a unique opportunity for trade unions to gain a foothold and have influence over work related decisions in this sector and this measure is supported by the French government. Indeed, a national French trade union, the CGT, has argued that it will use the law as an opportunity to find its footing again on union territory.

The motion before us today calls for a review of this French legislation to consider its application in the Australian context. The OECD has conducted a number of studies of work sharing initiatives, particularly given the growing interest in these practices in Europe. Because countries have different indicators of growth, productivity and employment outcomes, difficulties do arise in the development of an effective methodology to study work sharing initiatives between countries. A number of studies have concluded that precise results cannot be calculated, and this is especially so in the French situation, where industrial regulations are tightly regulated and subject to a complex and interwoven legislative framework. Although still in its implementation stage, the Aubry law has had a mixed reception from both employer and trade union organisations. The principal employer organisation in France, the CNPF, remains critical of the reduction in statutory working hours to 35 hours per week, and many sector level employer federations have had to scrap and redraft collective agreements to accommodate the Aubry law changes. The central argument of this law is that work sharing arrangements should create employment, that it should not encourage deployment.

An article in last week's Business Queensland on long working hours recounts the saga of Dupont in Australia in dramatically increasing productivity and preventing a plant closure. During that saga, the staff were called together and the situation was explained. They backed the company and worked longer hours. The reason that staff did this? They were part of a process that incorporated their ideas within a company vision. The result for Dupont Australia was that the local plant was so successful that they increased the distribution of chemicals to Japan. I conclude by saying that any review of legislation to reduce the number of working hours should not be limited to the French legislation and that we have a different situation here in Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe employment debate in Australia is incomplete, and has been for a long timeâ at least 20 years. Employment equations continue to bedevil governments of all political persuasions around the world. In the last 50 years in the developed world, capitalisation has quadrupled, productivity has tripled, energy consumption has tripled, butâand here is the real catchâemployment has only grown by a third.

speech.para: I said at the outset that the employment debate in this country is incomplete. It could also be accused of being dishonest. Until about 1980, employment rates were reasonably accurate in this country and instances of underemployment and overemployment were not highly significant. That has all changed. Although I cannot substantiate the following figures, the more important point is that they cannot satisfactorily be disputed either. For an unemployment rate of seven per cent, read 700,000 people without a job. But on top of those 700,000 you could add another seven per cent, or another 700,000 people, who are underemployedâin other words, they want to work full time but cannot. And yet there is another seven per cent, another 700,000 people, who want to work but are excluded from the labour market. That makes 2.1 million people affected by unemployment. But it is much worse than that. Increasing numbers of Australians are working longer and longer hours. What a paradox!

As the developed world creates a more and more chronic and endemic unemployment problem, attempts are made to reduce official rates of employment by misrepresentation of casual employment, underemployment and yet for others exclusion from the labour market, and then overemployment. But there is one absolute: current economic orthodoxies appear incapable of solving the problem.

Economic growth alone will not solve the unemployment problem or the overemployment problem. As stated in the motion by the member for Charlton, almost one-third of Australian workers are now working more than 50 hours per week. You only have to read the ABS to find that out. That is happening when possibly up to 2.1 million Australian workers are unemployed, underemployed or not even counted in the labour market statistics. I am not suggesting that a reduction in working time, as suggested by the French legislation, on its own can solve the unemployment and underemployment problem. However, no analysis of the employment debate will be complete if working time reorganisation is omitted. In fact, one of the criticisms in the analysis of Working Nation was that it ignored the reduction in working time.

Several years ago John Moorhouse, from the University of South Australia, pointed out that, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, 20 million hours of overtime were worked in Australia and since 1978 overtime for males has increased by 78 per cent and for women by over 100 per cent. A simple notion of 20 million hours of work equates to 500,000 40-hour per week jobs. It is understood that not all those overtime hours are paid overtime. Nevertheless, I believe it is a reasonable proposition to suggest that, given serious consideration, at least 100,000 and possibly 200,000 jobs could be released.

It is true that many people in labour market studies have shaftedâas the member for Petrie didâthe reduction in working hours propositions. But, essentially, the criticisms by some academics, bureaucrats and financial writers are purely economic. They take little or no account of the social costs of unemployment with increased crime, suicide and depression. Nor do they mention an inefficient economy with fragile and increased occupational health and safety hazards, lost productivity caused by fatigue and boredomâand productivity in this country has not gone too far in 20 yearsâincreased compensation claims blowing out of the sky and redundancy payouts common as dirt. The criticisms are in fact wrong.

Many economists suggest that the proposals for reducing working hours suffer from an argument called a `lump of output fallacy'âthat is, the total amount of work to be done is fixed and therefore the only way to employ more people is to share the work more frequentlyâthat is, in and out of employment. That is nonsense. In the last 100 years, the lifetime hours of work for men have fallen from probably more than 160,000 to around 80,000. Is anyone suggesting productivity fell during that period? Is anyone suggesting capital investment fell? Of course not. The `lump of output fallacy' is a discredited argument.

Reducing working hours and job sharing will not on their own solve the unemployment problem. However, the arguments for reduction of working hours must be analysed and given serious consideration in a more complete debate on employment. I conclude my remarks with a quote from Thomas Carlyle:

quote.para: Work is the grand cure of all the maladies and miseries that ever beset mankind.

talk.start.para: âI welcome the opportunity today to talk about this important issue of working hours and I congratulate the member for Charlton for raising it. I enjoyed listening to the contributions of the member for Port Adelaide and the member for Petrie. At the turn of a new centuryânow well into the 21st centuryâit is appropriate to discuss what is a reasonable working week. There are all sorts of social changes occurring within our society and, as the member for Port Adelaide acknowledged, while the model for Australia may not be derived from the French Socialist government, there is no particular philosophical opposition in lawâif there is, it should be looked atâto a set working hours week.

speech.para: We know that there has been a great casualisation and feminisation of the work force and that technology and mechanisation has occurred at a rate that has fundamentally changed and will continue to change the work force. I will not propose to try to define an ideal of what those hours should be in the three or four minutes I haveâUtopia is very much in the mind of the beholderâbut clearly there is plenty of scope for creativity, for the enjoyment of the new technology and for an improving outcome for Australian workers. However, if you were to legislate on the French model, would you bring MPs under that model? Would we be required to work only 35 hours and how would you actually do that? I am sure that we would debate that. Nevertheless, for the people of Australia, it is reasonable to say that there is a very much lower union participation rate, there are enterprise agreements, there are share ownership issues and the question of what today constitutes full employment, with our quite strong welfare system which does give a reasonable safety net.

I have particular concerns about working hours as they impact on the family, particularly where there are two parents working. The government has endeavoured to strike a better balance for families with younger children, because it is important that children be well cared for whatever the parents' situationâwhether it is in child care or child care combined with quality care in home.
It is a worthwhile discussion to have. I have a couple of things that I could throw across to the opposition. Simon Crean, the shadow Treasurer, when asked about Labor's industry policy, said:

quote.para: ... I think we have to admit that we didn't get it all right ...

speech.para: That is an interesting statement made on ABC Radio National on 11 August 1997. So there are challenges for the full parliamentâ not just for the coalition but for the Labor Party as well. I have, as I have indicated, no particular strong philosophical opposition to working hours that are fair and reasonable, but instead of laying down a 35-hour or a 39-hour working week we really want to protect that freedom which is critical. I challenge my colleagues: how do you regulate the working hours of a politician? We would really need to have an open, transparent approach to this and it is a discussion well worth having. I congratulate the member for Charlton for her contribution.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for next sitting.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âMy grievance today relates to the question of body image. I was motivated to speak in this place on this issue by a May edition of the Sunday Herald Sun, which I have here now. On page 1, there is a huge photo of Geri Halliwell, formerly Ginger Spice, in a bikini. The headline is `Look Who's Lost Weight'. The article commences with high approval of the fact that Geri Halliwell has lost 13 kilograms and is now described as `super slim'. The very attractive shot of her in a bikini is displayed next to a very unattractive shot of her when she clearly weighed more.

speech.para: The whole message is that women are to be valued for their bodies. Never mind the fact that, even with the extra 13 kilograms, Geri Halliwell would have been at a perfectly acceptable weight in terms of health. The article is concerning enough in and of itself because of its likely effect on the perception of women and girls about matters related to body image, but the thing that completely amazed me about this edition of the Herald Sun and motivated me to raise the matter in this place was the fact that in the very same edition of the newspaperâindeed, leading from the Geri Halliwell pieceâwas an article headed `selling starvation'. As members can see, the article is accompanied by photographs of very emaciated girls wearing high fashion items. This articleâI will read the first two paragraphs for the Houseâsays:

quote.para: Sickening websites that promote deadly eating disorders and glorify starving women and stick-thin celebrities are thriving on the Internet.
More than 100 shocking `proanorexia' websites encouraging women to starve themselves can be accessed by vulnerable young Australians at the click of a computer mouse.

speech.para: So we have in the one edition of the Herald Sun this incredibly disturbing juxtaposition. On the one hand, on page 1, we have an article in which a woman is being lauded for losing weight and yet, further into the newspaper, we have an article which is railing against eating disorders and, particularly, anorexia. This is a great illustration of the conundrum facing women about body image. They are told on the one hand by the media that it is desirable to be super thin; they are told on the other hand by the media that one needs to watch out for eating disorders. One wonders, if one is a woman, how you win this game.

I know that a number of women's magazines have put forward the view that the media cult of ultra-thinness is abating and we are on our way back to a more realistic view of body image. Frankly, I dispute this and believe there is as much reason to be concerned now as there ever was. A clear example of this phenomenon is the Ally McBeal television program and the continuing debate about the weight of its star Calista Flockhart. There has been a great deal of commentary about whether or not Flockhart has an eating disorder or is just naturally thin. I think the facts speak for themselves. Calista Flockhart is 166 centimetres tallâor five foot 5Â½ inches. She weighs what is described as `not quite' 42 kilogramsâor six stone six pounds. That is not a healthy weight for an adult woman, and the charts issued by the Australian Nutrition Foundation show her to be clearly in the underweight range.

The culture that drives the body image of Flockhart and others who star in the Ally McBeal show was revealing, detailed in an article in this week's Sunday Life magazine of, once again, the Sunday Herald Sun. The article details an interview with Vonda Shepard, who is the singer on Ally McBeal and features in each episode. She states:

quote.para: Is there pressure on me to stay slim because I'm in Ally McBeal? Of course there is. There's pressure on everyone ... I wish it wasn't the case but Hollywood pressurises women into staying super-thin.

speech.para: Shepard is described in the article as being 173 centimetres tall and weighing 60 kilogramsâthat is, she is five foot seven inches and weighs nine stone six pounds. At that weight for height, Shepard would fall at the lower end of the healthy weight range, as defined by the Australian Nutrition Foundation. She expresses in the article a desire to lose three kilograms, a reduction which would take her into the underweight range. Shepard says about her lifestyle:

quote.para: I work out six days a week for at least an hour and a half at a time. I know that it's part of my job to stay thin. I know that I'm healthy but I would always love to be thinner.

speech.para: She goes on:

quote.para: You never see anyone eat (that is on the Ally McBeal set). But we're all on the same diet ... it's just salad and steamed vegetable, and maybe a little bit of protein such as grilled fish or boiled chicken without the skin. Salad dressing is always on the side. No pasta. No bread. It's so boring. I hate it. I've started letting myself have pasta once a week just to feel normal. But the pressure to be thin is overwhelming in this town.
Everywhere I go, there are girls skinnier than me.

speech.para: Another star of the show, Courtney Thorne-Smith, actually quit the series, claiming she had been pushed to the brink of anorexia. Thorne-Smith has said:

quote.para: The truth is I was systematically depleting myself physically, by under eating and over-exercising ... to be impossibly thin.

speech.para: If this were just a matter involving a few individual women, it would be a private tragedy. But it is so much more than that, because the media imagery of super thin as desirable has a clear effect on women and girls. I will take the House through some statistics in that regard. The women's Health Australia Survey found that adult women who diet frequently were 50 per cent more likely to be depressed than those who did not diet. A 1999 survey found that 62 per cent of girls who were described as extreme dieters reported high levels of depression and anxiety. Adolescent girls who diet only moderately are five times more likely to develop an eating disorder than girls who do not diet. Young Australian women who start dieting before the age of 15 are more likely to experience depression, binge eating and purging. Girls who diet severely are 18 times more likely to develop an eating disorder than girls who do not diet. A total of 50 per cent of primary schoolchildren want to weigh less, 30 per cent of women and 17 per cent of men are on diets, and 26 to 30 per cent of boys want to be thinner. More than half Melbourne's schoolgirls, aged 15 to 16, are on diets, even though 49 per cent are a normal weight and at least 20 per cent are underweight. Only 1.6 per cent of young Australian women say they are happy about their weight. About 2,000 calls a year to the Kids Help Line are solely regarding self-image issues. In general, girls make two-thirds of the calls to the Kids Help Line, but there are a significant number of boys who ring to express their fears, doubts and troubles. Almost half of these callers state they are experiencing persistent feelings of low self-value or severe feelings of worthlessness.

Against this background and the damage it causes, why does the media idolise super thin as the best body type? That I think is a very difficult question to answer. The super-thin stereotype is of course not our historic vision of beauty. Marilyn Monroe was a curvaceous 37-23-36. Of course, in those days we measured inches. In the last 25 years we have moved from the hourglass stereotype to the super-thin one. I would venture the view that this change has not occurred because of some radical shift in the view of men about what are sexually attractive female body shapes. Indeed, I suspect that most heterosexual men would indicate a preference for the Marilyn Monroe body shape over the Calista Flockhart one.

However, I think this shift in media stereotypes of body image is related to the changes in women's roles. I note with approval a female comedian's pithy statement that the last 100 years for women could be viewed as a shift from emancipation to emaciation: `No, don't give me a whole vote; I couldn't possible finish it.' Our cultural understanding, as reflected by the media, needs to urgently move from emaciation back to emancipation and from emaciation to realityâto move to an understanding that an individual's value is not about appearance and that beauty and self-worth cannot be measured in kilograms.

subdebateinfo.title: Petrie Electorate: Redcliffe Peninsula Rail Link and Houghton and Bruce Highways

talk.start.para: âI want to congratulate the member for Lalor on a fine speech, and I agree with her wholeheartedly.

speech.para: I rise today to bring to the House's attention the consistent failure of the Beattie government and the state member for Redcliffe, Mr Ray Hollis, to honour their promise for a rail link to the Redcliffe Peninsula. The state government announced in the budget that $5.5 million would be spent for a third rail line from Northgate to Petrie. The member for Murrumba, Dean Wells, on page 4 of the Redcliffe Herald on 20 June, said that a third line was a necessary precondition for the rail link from Petrie to Kippa-Ring. He goes on to say:

quote.para: ... this does not mean the government is going ahead with building the Kippa-Ring link but it does demonstrate that we are serious about providing the connection in the medium to long term.

speech.para: How long is medium to long term for the state government? It is a bit like asking how long is a piece of string. We have been waiting for this railway for 100 years. How long is the short to medium to long term? I would like to know. When the state member for Redcliffe was returned for his fifth consecutive term, he told the local Redcliffe Herald on 28 February of this year that the long-promised rail link was now in its planning stages. In fact, he declared that rail was one of two `high priorities'. The other priority was the duplication of the Houghton Highway. He made this very bold statement that the promised rail link was in its planning stages, with the location of stations being considered and consultation on property access for local landowners in progress.

A quick look at a June 2000 document by Queensland Transport on the Petrie to Kippa-Ring transport corridor already lists the sites of the proposed stations and refers back to the 1980s when a rail link to the peninsula was first touted. That effectively means that during the entirety of the member for Redcliffe's term in office he has done little to advance this rail link beyond its planning stages. All we see from the member for Redcliffe is feasibility study after feasibility study after feasibility study. A feasibility study becomes out of date: another feasibility study is ordered. The recent budget announcement provided improved access for all lines north of Brisbane. Although it may one day benefit the proposed Redcliffe and peninsula rail link, it is not included in the planning document by Queensland Transport as part of that plan.

When Mr Hollis was returned for his fifth term he made the duplication of the Houghton Highway, the longest bridge of its type in the Southern Hemisphere, his second priority, along with the rail link. He was quoted in the local press as saying that he saw a second bridge as a definite prospect and alluded to the fact that this may take effect in the next five years or so. In that article he said:

quote.para: I'll be working very hard this year to see that planning is put in place for a second bridge to Redcliffe as soon as possible.

speech.para: During the state election the Beattie government announced that $1.6 million would be spent on upgrading the safety features of the 21-year-old Houghton Highway. Last week's budget announced a $1.25 million spending proposal to complete installation of traffic management systems to upgrade the tidal flow lane control system on the Houghton Highway bridge, thus improving its efficiency and safety. However, Mr Hollis did not announce this funding in his interview with the local paper.

When I announced back in April an additional $40 million for the Bruce Highway upgrade, I received a scathing letter from the member for Redcliffe, Mr Hollis, regarding the spending of funds on a road that `effectively abandoned Redcliffe'. Mr Hollis, I must tell you that I have not abandoned Redcliffe. Mr Hollis also forwarded this letter to the local press. In his letter he said that the announcement of the $40 million upgradeâ in addition to the $35 million that I had already obtained in funding for stage 1 of the highway, which began in January of this yearâeffectively abandoned Redcliffe by forcing an end to hopes for the duplication of the Houghton Highway in the foreseeable future. The Houghton Highway, for the member for Redcliffe's information, is a state road, and it is his responsibility to do something about improving the conditions on that highway. It is called a highway, but it is a state road. Mr Hollis claimed that the Bruce Highway upgrade would make this route the primary access route to Redcliffe. In fact, Mr Hollis made the claim:

quote.para: No government, State or Federal, would be able to justify such expenditure on a secondary route.

speech.para: Interesting words when less than two months previously he had said the duplication of the bridge was a definite prospect. But Mr Hollis was just repeating the Labor mantra of `blame the Howard government'. It is interesting to note that Mr Hollis's own colleague, Steve Bredhauer, the Minister for Transport, wrote to me late last year urging me to lobby for more funds for the Bruce Highway. In his letter he said that Queensland's major priority on the national highway system in the Sunshine Coast corridor includes eight and six lanes between Pine River and Caboolture. The $40 million plus the $35 million contributed to this route by the federal government in extending the roadworks from Pine Rivers bridge up to Burpengary includes Mr Bredhauer's wish list of eight and six lanes between Pine River and the Caboolture region.

In last week's state budget $29 million was pledged by the state government to assist the upgrade. I am proud of the $75 million in funding that has been delivered to my region for the Bruce Highway. I have delivered that for the people of the northern and outer northern regions of Brisbane. In my 1998 election promise I pledged that I would increase funding and lobby for funding for this vital route that serves a number of my constituents. Contrary to what the member for Redcliffe claims, the upgrade of the Bruce Highway does not abandon Redcliffe.

The Bruce Highway is the major arterial road northbound from Brisbane. Funds will alleviate the most congested northbound route out of Brisbane at peak times. Each day between 48,000 and 72,000 vehicles use the route between the Pine River bridge and Caboolture, and around nine per cent of these vehicles are commercial. This upgrade will improve travel time for commuters and delivery times for agricultural and manufactured goods to cities and regions north of Brisbane. Tourism is the largest industry in Queensland, and the upgrade of the highway will provide a world standard motorway for the thousands of visitors who come to Queensland during their Australian visits. Close to half of the international visitors to Australia also include Queensland in their stay, and many of those visitors use road transport.

These funds will deliver to the people of Brisbane and Brisbane's outer northern regionâan area where Beattie's government has failed to deliver adequate public transport. The city of Redcliffe, in the outer north of Brisbane, has a population of approximately 58,000. A council survey during the 1990s found that, of those people in the available work force, approximately 67 per cent worked outside the city and around 13,000 of these worked in Brisbane. There are two ways to get to Brisbane: you can go along the Bruce Highway, accessible from Anzac Avenue, or you can use the Houghton Highway. Commuters can catch a bus along the Houghton Bridge to Sandgate and pick up a rail link there.

The upgrade of the Bruce Highway will benefit the people of Redcliffe. It will benefit those people living in Mango Hill and also those who live in Rothwell. This is the third fastest growing region in Australia. It is populated mostly by young families. It is estimated that in 10 to 15 years Mango Hill will grow by some 25,000 people. The growth alone is expected to increase the local work force by 13,000. Redcliffe city will be one of the beneficiaries of the Bruce Highway upgrade, as will Mango Hill and Rothwell. Those people along that highway have little option but to drive to work in Brisbane.

Five years for a rail link is a long time for the people of the peninsula to continue to experience congestion in their travel to Brisbane, and increasing the time spent travelling to and from work will depreciate their quality of life. The state government have failed consistently to provide adequate public transport for these communities, yet they gripe when funding is given and delivered to them. I ask that they stop griping and complaining and get on with doing something about fixing up the Houghton Highway and creating a link from the Redcliffe Peninsula. We have been isolated for long enough. The federal government's funds will see an improvement in both the travel time and quality of life for the 13,000 people who travel and who are regular commuters and drive the 70,000 vehicles that use this route every day. I am looking forward to seeing the completion of this highway that will make it a world-class highway and deliver benefits to the people in my region.

talk.start.para: âI rise today in the grievance debate to refer to the management and operation of gene technology regulation in this country, and to highlight some of the issues around the recently launched Interim Office of the Gene Technology Regulator. Firstly, I would like to refer to an article from the Weekend Australian on 16 June 2001 by Natasha Bita. Titled `Crop busters', the article essentially goes through what the situation is going to be in terms of regulation of gene technology in Australia now that the regulator is going into play. I would like to read a couple of quotes from the article:

quote.para: âThis legislation has been a long time coming,â says the regulator's acting head, Elisabeth Cain. âFrom June 21 this is law. We're going to be out there on the ground monitoring it in a hands-on wayâinspections, audits and checks of procedures.

âWhen we identified the non-compliance in Tasmania, it wasn't because the companies came forward and said, `How ya going Liz? We think we've stuffed up a bit.' It was because I had our guys out there checking they were doing as they should, and they weren't.â

speech.para: The article also reads:

quote.para: Cain, however, is adamant that the location of all 120 GM test sites in Australia will be listed on the regulator's website on Thursday.

â[Aventis] is not correct,â she says. âIt's very clear in the legislation we are releasing the field trial site locations. That's what people want to know. It would be nonsense for me to tell my mother-in-law about GPS coordinates when she wants to know if the farmer down the road is trialling GM crops.â

speech.para: I would like to go through a couple of points with respect to that quote. The tenor of the article is very much supportive of the gene tech regulator and the fact that this is a new tough and rigorous system which will dramatically improve what has been occurring around this area. I hope that that is the case, but I do have some doubts because of the history of gene tech regulation in this country, particularly over the last couple of years. For example, look at what happened in Tasmania. I would like to read from a media statement from David Llewellyn, the state Minister for Primary Industries, Water and Environment, headed `Duplicity from the federal government'. I am going to read this in its entirety because I think it makes very clear what the Tasmanian government thought about the Interim Office of the Gene Technology Regulator in terms of the work it was doing:

quote.para: The Federal Government's duplicitous and dishonest approach to the issue of GMO breaches in Tasmania has been revealed in State Parliament today.

Minister for Primary Industries, Water and Environment, David Llewellyn, said the Federal Government through its Interim Office of Gene Technology Regulator (IOTGR), had refused a demand from the State Government to provide detailed information of the breaches as required under Tasmania's Plant Quarantine Act.
âThis is the height of arrogance from the Federal Government. They are treating Tasmanians like country cousins.

âThis paternalistic and patronising attitude that they know what's best for Tasmania on this issue is abhorrent. They are deliberately keeping this information from the State Government, despite our legal right to have it.

âNot only has the Federal Government been negligent in their monitoring of GM crops in Tasmania, they have refused, despite repeated requests, to provide us with either the compliance reportânow three weeks oldâand now the details of the problem sites as required by our Plant Quarantine Act.â

Mr Llewellyn said the head of the IOGTR Liz Cain had acted to deliberately mislead and confuse journalists and the public on several fronts. Ms Cain told journalists (see Mercury March 3) that she was unaware of requests from the State Government for detailed information about the site locations. Those requests were made both to her office and to Ms Cain personally by DPIWE officers.

Ms Cain also told journalists in Hobart that âif the State Government is concerned about non-compliance with state legislation (ie: the Plant Quarantine Act), [it] has absolute power to access all the information ... and that would include site location.â (The Examiner, 3 March 2001).
She is now refusing to provide the State Government with the information as demanded under the Plant Quarantine Act.
Mr Llewellyn said Ms Cain's comments were little more than rhetoric to shield the Federal Government from criticism.
âLiz Cain has shown she has no intention of co-operating with the Tasmanian Government or working with it on this issue. Her words are empty.
âShe has instead challenged the advice of Solicitor General Bill Baleâdeclining to provide the documents and information sought.â
Mr Llewellyn said the Federal Government had also reneged on its promise that Tasmania would be involved in follow-up monitoring of the breaches.

âOfficers of the IOGTR were in Tasmania last week monitoring the sites where the problems have occurred. The Federal Government again failed Tasmanians miserably by not honouring their commitment for my officers to be part of the Monitoring team.
âThey didn't even have the courtesy of advising my Department they would be in the state.

âI have now instructed officers of my Department to visit every one of those trial sites in Tasmania to satisfy the Government that no further contamination exists, and to take samples of any material found and samples from surrounding areas that may be necessary.â

speech.para: In terms of the Tasmanian government's view on the actions of the IOGTR with respect to breaches in Tasmania, they thought it was so well done that there was a need to put out a press release like that and to instigate checks by the Tasmanian government themselves.

When we look at the actions by the IOGTR with respect to monitoring, there really was not much monitoring going on in relation to GM sites around the country until a story was broken in about March last year by the Age regarding a problem in Mount Gambier with respect to a herbicide tolerant canola site that is being trialled by Aventis. Essentially, only after those allegations was any inquiry made by the IOGTR. Following that, there was quite a bit of criticism about the IOGTR's actions at that time. I would like to read from the report Work in progress: proceed with caution regarding primary producer access to gene technology. That report, dated June 2000, is from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Primary Industries and Regional Services, a committee of which I am a member. As members would know, that committee has members from both sides of the House and even an independent on it. That committee, on an unanimous basis, found the following:

quote.para: The committee was very concerned to hear allegations earlier this year that Aventis' (formerly AgrEvo) trials of herbicide tolerant canola in the Mount Gambier area of South Australia had breached GMAC guidelines. It is even more worried by the manner in which the IOGTR has investigated the alleged breaches, in particular its tardiness in completing its investigation. The IOGTR began its examination of the allegations on 24 March 2000 and, as at 18 May, the results of this examination had not even been forwarded to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, let alone been publicly released.

The committee is of the view that the alleged breaches would have been much less likely to have occurred if stringent, transparent regulatory processes, such as those described in the next sections of this chapter, had been in place. The committee is unanimous in believing that rigorous, independent regulatory processes must be instituted as quickly as possible. A more prompt, open, transparent approach must be taken to breaches of guidelines. It is essential that the OGTR act much more efficiently and effectively than the IOGTR has been able to if it is to reassure the Australian people that their interests are being strenuously protected. If this does not happen, public confidence in GMOs and their regulation will be badly prejudiced.

speech.para: I would like to say that we have seen significant improvements since that time, but I have some real concerns about what has happened in this area as recently as the last couple of days. The legislation was passed in the end with the support of the opposition. We worked closely with the government in order to ensure that some amendments were put in place that would improve the transparency of the system and place more publicly available information on the record in order to ensure that there was a rigorous capacity to understand what the regulator was doing and in that way ensure a better regulatory system. We were not totally happy with what was passed, although we believed that, other than in a couple of areas, it was very good legislation. I concur with the view of the government that at this stage the legislation is world's best practice, although I think it still could have been improved to a degree. The important thing was that we needed to get a system in place and, if we did not get a system in place sooner rather than later, then the problems which already existed would get much worse. But what have we seen?

Having some six months to address the legislation's implementation and with Ms Cain being on the record as saying that six months would be enough time to do so, we saw a situation where, when the system was in operation last Thursday, only about half the applications for deliberate releases into the environment were on the web site. Of the applications that are there, about half of them have commercial-in-confidence claims being put on them by those who submitted them, about the question of location of sites. We saw a range of information that was on the previous GMAC public information sheets not included in the information that is currently on the web siteâone would hope that will be remedied in the near future. And we saw a situation where although, for example, there were blanket removals of applications by Aventis and Monsanto claiming commercial-in-confidence, we also saw 11 out of 30 applications from the CSIRO seeking to keep location details secret. In total, out of the 30 that are there, overwhelmingly it is government organisations who are asking for these exemptions. That is a very bad start for the new system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday I want to grieve about the state of the Murray-Darling Basin and perhaps come up with a suggestion which the Commonwealth government might like to take up with a view to improving the regulation of the Murray-Darling Basinânamely, that a referendum be held to remove the power over the Murray-Darling Basin from the states and give it to the Commonwealth government. To do that would require the removal of section 100 from the Constitution and the placing of a new head of power under section 51 of the Constitution saying something like `the control and regulation of the Murray and Darling River Basin and the use of the water thereof'.

speech.para: This is not a new issue; it is a very old issue which goes right back to the Federation debates in the 1890s, particularly in Adelaide in 1897 and also in Melbourne in 1898 where South Australia and other states came very close to giving power over the Murray-Darling Basin to the Commonwealth government but were defeated in their efforts by the activities of George Houston Reid, who was the Premier of New South Wales and went on to be the Prime Minister of Australia. He defeated South Australia in its efforts to have this as a Commonwealth controlled area, but now 100 years later the evidence is overwhelming that it is pointless leaving the Murray-Darling Basin in the hands of the states when they have proved themselves incapable of managing such an important resource for Australia.

In the 1890s, it was the navigation of the waterways that was at issue in the convention debates. Today, the economic and ecological importance of the Murray-Darling Basin is undisputed, yet it remains in the hands of the states, who bicker about it and fail to achieve consensus about how it should be approached. As a consequence, the Murray River is slowly dying and the people of Adelaide and all along the Murray who rely on it for water are the sufferers. Australia as a whole is suffering because of the selfishness of some states in their approach to the Murray-Darling Basin. I single out particularly for comment the state of Queensland, which is peculiarly selfish with respect to the water that flows into the Darling and should then be flowing into the Murray but is not.

I would propose that the power should be a concurrent power so that the states would be entitled to continue to legislate with respect to the Murray-Darling Basin but that any laws that they introduced that were at odds with the Commonwealth power would be invalid and the Commonwealth power would override whatever state law was in place to govern a particular aspect of the management of the Murray-Darling Basin system. There is ample evidence to show that there are good reasons for the people to vote in a referendum to give the Commonwealth power over the Murray-Darling Basin. These include the major environmental issues that need to be addressed: in-stream and dryland salinity, over-allocation of water to consumption, land clearance, soil structure decline and water and wind erosion.

The Australian dryland salinity assessment 2000 identified some of the following issues in the Murray-Darling Basin and its subcatchments: by 2050 over 40 per cent of wetlands within the Goulburn-Broken region will be in landscapes with shallow water tables; in the Murray Basin of South Australia, the estimated area affected by salinity in 1998 was 19,800 hectares, and this is expected to increase to 29,600 hectares in 2020 and 34,000 hectares in 2050; ground water modelling suggests that vegetation clearance in the Mallee will cause salinity to increase by 115 electrical conductivity units by 2050 at Morgan, costing consumers an additional $16Â½ million each year; and areas at risk from rising water tables include extensive tea-tree shrub lands and native grasses in the Coorong district and seasonal wetlands and watercourses in the upper south-east. And that is not all. The National Land and Water Resources Audit's Australian water resources assessment 2000 also noted the following trends in water quality issues: the Lower Murray recorded total nutrients, phosphorus and nitrogen levels that exceeded the audit's water quality guidelines; salinity readings exceeded the audit's water quality levels at monitoring stations from all the South Australian river basins, thereby indicating the widespread nature of salinity as a water quality issue in South Australia; and the Lower Murray also exceeded the water quality values for turbidity. The Murray-Darling Basin Commission's salinity audit also raised major concerns that Adelaide's drinking water will be undrinkable two out of every five days within 20 years.

Even today in the Advertiser there is further evidence of the mismanagement of the Murray-Darling Basin by the states, with calls for the federal government to take over control of the management of the murray cod. A new report has shown that the species is `seriously threatened'. The Advertiser says:

quote.para: The report listed the six main threats to the Murray cod as habitat degradation, pollution (including cold water pollution from deep dams) inappropriate river flow, migration barriers such as weirs, introduced species such as European carp and commercial, recreational and illegal fishing.

speech.para: The Advertiser indicated that the report said:

quote.para: State governments currently set the rules regarding cod but Senator Hill said he would instruct his department to investigate whether the fish should be given Commonwealth conservation status.
Senator Hill said it was odd that there were different state laws regarding cod when the fish lived in the same river system.

speech.para: I could not agree more with Senator Hill. It does seem odd, even on an issue like the murray cod, which is a threatened species in the Murray, that still the states attach their own particular rules and regulations to the management of the murray cod and have put that fish at risk. Some people will say, `Well, it's a minor issue whether the murray cod survives or not,' but the reality is that it is a pointer to the ecological health of the Murray and Darling River basins. Clearly, from all the evidence that I have tabled todayâfrom the assessments given by government departments and in anecdotal evidence in today's Advertiserâthere is a very strong case that the states have mismanaged the Murray-Darling Basin system and that the Commonwealth should take it over. The only way that can be done is if the people give us the power to do so through a referendum.

The Queensland government is particularly egregious in its attitude towards the other states, and particularly South Australia, in its management of the Darling Basin. On something as simple, obvious and logical as capping the amount of water taken from the basin, the Queensland government has still failed to sign up to the capping agreements that have been in place since 1997 based on water taken in 1993 and 1994. South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria have all signed up to water capping agreements in 1997, based on water taken in the early nineties, and Queensland has still failed to sign up to these capping arrangements and still puts them off, obfuscates and throws up hurdles in the path of simple and logical measures like capping the water taken from the Darling system that is to flow into the Murray. In fact, in the case of the Condamine River, every drop of water is taken from the Condamine River that would normally have flowed into the Darling River and then into the Murray River. Of course, this is a modern phenomenon. In history, the Condamine River would have flowed into the Darling and the Darling would have flowed into the Murray but, because of the actions of technology and state government ineptitude, particularly from the Queensland state government, the flow of rivers is being stopped that would normally have flowed into the Darling and then into the Murray.

I do not believe that the Queensland government ever intends to sign the capping agreements that the other states have signed. They have shown in other areas as wellâ particularly in the area of land clearingâthat they have no regard at all for the environment, for the future of our children and for our grandchildren, and they do not care about the pressure placed on them by other states or by the Commonwealth government. So I am asking that the Commonwealth proceed with a referendum at the next federal election to delete section 100 from the Constitution and replace it with a head of power under section 51 that would give the Commonwealth power over the Murray-Darling Basin. The Advertiser editorial from some weeks ago makes this comment:

quote.para: At the very least a national vote among the states and territories would give the Murray'sâand this state'sâfuture the priority it demands and generate the awareness it requires.

speech.para: I hope that the Commonwealth will listen to my call and heed it. I look forward to the opportunity to cast a vote to give the Commonwealth the much needed power over the Murray-Darling Basin.

talk.start.para: â Not long after I was elected to this parliament, I was approached by a number of residents who have been trying for many years to have Cranbourne included in the Melbourne telephone call zone. Cranbourne is presently outside the Melbourne call zone, and this is inconsistent with telephone charging arrangements in other suburban areas and nearby towns. For instance, Mount Eliza is further from Melbourne than Cranbourne but it is in the Melbourne call zone. Cranbourne is outside the Melbourne zone for historical reasons, as it was once a country town, but times have changed and so has Cranbourne. It is now very much part of the metropolitan area. Technology has changed too, and there is now no good argument for continuing to exclude Cranbourne from the Melbourne call zone.

speech.para: Earlier this year, I tabled a petition signed by more than 3,500 people calling for Cranbourne to be included in the Melbourne call zone. In April 2000, Telstra announced its zoning review and the outcomes of the review were finally made public last week, some eight months after the expected date. It is very disappointing that the outcomes do not provide the relief Cranbourne residents and businesses were looking for. It is also disappointing that the new arrangements include complicated choices for consumers, and it is not clear that many people will actually benefit from these proposed changes. The key point here is that the review has not moved the zone boundaries and Cranbourne is still considered to be outside Melbourne. A look at the map of the zone boundaries shows a decided kink around Cranbourneâa kink in the wrong direction and leaving Cranbourne out in the cold. The fact that this most recent review was conducted by Telstra itself, and not by an independent body, makes the outcomes more difficult to accept. Labor has called for an independent review as the only way to ensure a thorough and fair review of the current zone arrangements. On a slightly different tack, these new arrangements do nothing for those who do not use Telstra as their carrier. There are no announced changes to wholesale prices.

The new arrangements are very complicated. At first glance, the offer of a 25c flat call rate to Melbourne is good news, but once the fine print is read, the good news disappears. Consumers who take on the wide area call option lose their access to neighbourhood calls at 15c and will now have to pay 22c for these calls. It should also be pointed out that any savings made under the new arrangements need to be offset against the recent increase in line rental of $2.26 per month. These new arrangements are not good enough for Cranbourne, for three reasons: firstly, Cranbourne is still not included in the Melbourne call zone, despite changes in demographics and technology since the zones were established; secondly, the new charging arrangements are only available to Telstra customers, and then not all Telstra customers; and, thirdly, the options are too complicated, leaving many consumers confused and suspicious.

Mr Deputy Speaker, let me tell you about Chicquita park. Chicquita park is an area of open space in suburban Mentone which is owned by the Department of Defence and which the department now wants to sell. I was approached last year by a group of local residents who are, understandably, upset at the thought of losing their park. I have been working with these residents to try to find a way of preserving the area as open space. The local council, Kingston, is also keen to see the area remain as open space. The department originally offered the land to Kingston council for something approaching $3 millionâan amount well beyond what Kingston can reasonably be expected to pay for an area to be kept as open land. The value was based on the land being zoned for residential purposes and not open space.

Earlier this year, as my office discussed the issue with officers within the Department of Defence, the message we were getting loud and clear was that the intention was to sell the land before the end of June 2001, come what may. The picture we were getting was that the government was hell-bent on selling the land, regardless of community concerns or even price. The risk at that stage was that the land would be sold quickly and at a less than optimal price, as zoning issues were still to be worked through. The risk was that, as a community, we would lose the open space but not get the optimum value for this lossâin other words, an outcome to no-one's benefit, except the purchaser.

Early in May this year I received two letters in quick succession from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence. Both letters indicate quite clearly that the government is determined to sell this land. The first letter, dated 4 May 2001, was in response to a letter from me to the minister dated 28 March 2001. The response simply sets out the history of the proposed sale. It also indicates a willingness on the minister's part to work through `relevant issues' with the council following advice from the council which was expected by the end of April. As this letter was dated 4 May, I can only assume that there was a delay between drafting and the parliamentary secretary signing the letter.

The second letter I received was dated 9 May 2001 and was in response to my letter to the minister and the parliamentary secretary on 17 April 2001. This second letter answered some of my more specific issues about the processes being followed. However, the letter also talked about a meeting with Kingston council and community group leaders on 10 May 2001âtoo late for me to be involved, despite my ongoing correspondence with the minister. I am disappointed that the parliamentary secretary did not see fit to invite me to this meeting, despite my ongoing correspondence with him on the matter and despite the fact that the Liberal candidate was invited. This is very poor and does no credit to the minister or his office. More importantly, though, this letter makes it very clear, again, that the land is to be sold.

About this time Kingston made an offer of $500,000 for the landâa fair price based on the land remaining as open space, but to date no response has been made by the minister or the department to this offer. Recent questions in the defence estimates committee pursued this matter and officers of the department indicated that the offer is most unlikely to be accepted. I am disturbed by the handling of this issue as it seems that the local community are being led a bit of a dance. A recent newspaper article in the Mordialloc-Chelsea News indicates the offer is being considered, but departmental officers have already said that the offer is most unlikely to be accepted. It is time for the minister to take a stand and announce that he will take steps to ensure the land remains as open space.

At the risk of repeating what I have said in this place and what others have said before me, I would now like to take a few minutes to express my dismay and that of Chelsea residents at yet another bank closure. In two weeks the Chelsea branch of the National Australia Bank will close. This follows the closure of the National Australia Bank in Mordialloc late last year and other bank closures earlier last year. The concern of the community is increasing as these closures just keep on coming. The NAB's announcement of the last two closures typifies the lack of care and concern the banks are displaying. Both announcements listed alternative branches available once the Mordialloc and Chelsea branches are closed. Needless to say, all the branches are some kilometres from Mordialloc and Chelsea, but two of the three alternatives are very difficult, if not impossible, to get to via public transport. Both of these branches are located in industrial areas a long way from residential areas. Anyone with local knowledge would not have suggested these as reasonable alternatives.

I find the fact that the bank did not take the time or effort to check out the facts indicative of the attitude that is growing dailyâthat household customers are not important and that adequate service to them is not critical. It is critical that all Australians have adequate access to financial services. This is so on social justice grounds and also economic efficiency grounds. The government must accept that the tin god called competition does not always provide what is necessary for people. Banks do have social obligations that go beyond commercial considerations and that are broader than the responsibilities of most other commercial organisations. The bank licence brings with it responsibilities as well as privileges, and it is time banks took those responsibilities more seriously.

I would like to take the last few minutes to congratulate Merinda Park Community Centre on receiving the Innovation Award in the City of Casey Community Volunteer Award Program recently. The award was won for Merinda Park's `Getting it together' training course. The course was judged to be good and innovative. The purpose of the course is to train volunteers to become effective mentors. The course was developed by Merinda Park in association with Youth Futures in Frankston. There are a number of older people in our community who have loads of life experience and who are keen to pass on their knowledge. There is a place in our community for these skilled older people to mentor and assist younger people. The course developed at Merinda Park focuses on the development of respect, trust and support in relationships and also provides participants with the skills necessary to become effective mentors. The mentors can then help young people in the area with support and guidance.

Volunteers are very important in our community, and this course provides an opportunity for volunteers to hone their mentoring skills and develop confidence in their ability to pass on their useful life skills to others. The course was developed for volunteers working with young people, but the skills it teaches can be applied to any situation where an experienced person is trying to help someone new in the field. I encourage other groups who use volunteers to contact Merinda Park to talk about this course and perhaps see how it can be useful to them.

talk.start.para: â Much has been said recently about the need to improve facilities within the immigration reception and processing centres to ensure that the government's policy of humane detention is adhered to. This is an important issue, and has been the subject of some ill informed, though perhaps well-meaning, criticism over the past few weeks. No-one is suggesting that this is not a very difficult, very complex issue indeedâto the contrary. Simplistic responses as proposed by some commentators have been tried in the past and have failed. When such comments are reported in the Australian and international media, they are seized upon by people smugglers. Illegal immigrants' expectations are raised unnecessarily so that they think that when they arrive in Australia they will be immediately released into the community or will be in detention for a very short period regardless of whether they have any genuine claims to remain.

speech.para: When refugees are advised that they have no right to remain in Australia, their unmet expectations give rise to a culture of protest and, in some cases, unlawful, riotous activity. All people commenting publicly on these matters in Australia should at least inform themselves of the global nature of the issue, the complexities and the involvement of criminal gangs and the sheer determination of many people to live in Australia. Today I received a copy of the 2000 edition of Protecting the border: immigration compliance, which is put out by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I want to quote a few figures from that publication, which certainly has changed my view of some of the comments that I have made in the past about what we should be doing with some of these illegal immigrants. On page 13, the publication gives some figures in relation to people-smuggling to Australia. It says:

quote.para: The total number of unauthorised arrivals in Australia increased from 1556 in 1994-95 to 5870 in 1999-2000.
Unauthorised air arrivals constituted 29 per cent of all unauthorised arrivals in 1999-2000.
Unauthorised boat arrivals constituted 71 per cent of all unauthorised arrivals in 1999-2000.

Iraq, Afghanistan, Iran, the PRC, Malaysia, South Korea, New Zealand, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Indonesia make up the top 10 countries or territories of citizenship for all unauthorised arrivals in 1999-2000.
The majority of unauthorised arrivals were aged 20-34 years.
People smugglers are using increasingly sophisticated methods.
The Australian Government has developed a comprehensive whole-of-government strategy to combat people smuggling and stem the illegal flow of people to Australia.

speech.para: This publication defines people-smuggling as follows:

quote.para: People smuggling involves the illegal movement of people across international borders, usually for payment. This implies a voluntary agreement between the organiser and the person being smuggled.

speech.para: It goes on to define people-trafficking as:

quote.para: ... the illegal movement of people, often against their will, across international borders. There is often ongoing exploitation to pay off a debt owed to the organiser. Traditionally, this has applied to people involved in the sex industry, but neither the definition nor the reality are limited to this form of employment.

speech.para: The figures continue. In relation to immigration malpractices detected, the publication says:

quote.para: Immigration malpractice detected at Australian airports in 1999-2000 included document fraud, malafide visa holders and identification of facilitators of irregular entry.
32 per cent of people refused immigration clearance presented either bogus documents or no documents at all.
The most common type of document fraud is a photo substituted passport.

63 per cent of people refused immigration clearance were considered to be malafide visa holders. Of those people who were refused immigration clearance on the basis of their bonafides, 21 per cent were from Malaysia.
In 1999-2000 ALOs intercepted 90 people in Bangkok, 105 in Singapore, 74 in Kuala Lumpur, 77 in Hong Kong SAR and 7 in Denpasar.
