speech.para: I want to continue to quote some of the figures, but it is very important to highlight the magnitude of the problem. I refer now to unauthorised boat arrivals. The publication says:

quote.para: There were 4175 unauthorised boat arrivals in 1999-2000, compared with 926 in 1998-99 and 157 in 1997-98.

speech.para: So the problem is escalating dramatically. The document continues:

quote.para: Of the 75 unauthorised boats in 1999-2000, 73 (97 per cent) embarked from Indonesia.
The main landing site for unauthorised boat arrivals in 1999-2000 were the Ashmore Islands and Christmas Island.
The top 3 countries or territories of citizenship for unauthorised boat arrivals in 1999-2000 were Iraq with 2297 arrivals, Afghanistan with 1263 and Iran with 227 unauthorised boat arrivals.
60 per cent of all unauthorised boat arrivals in 1999-2000 were aged between 20-34 years.
There were 331 illegal Indonesian fishermen apprehended in 1999-2000 by the Australian Fisheries Management Authority.

speech.para: Much has been said about Australia's activity under the refugees convention. We are required under that refugees convention to admit people who arrive in our territory in an unauthorised fashion where there is a question about them needing protection. Australia does this. We are not, however, required to permit full access to the Australian community until we know who they are and we have undertaken health character and security checking. Immigration detention in Australia is consistent with the UNHCR's detention guidelines and Excom's conclusions on this matter. It is designed to ensure that applicants are available while their claims are assessed, to facilitate identification, health, character and security assessment and to ensure that they remain available for removal from Australia should they prove not to be eligible for the grant of a visa.

That is why we have the policy of mandatory detention, which still has bipartisan support. These people are in Australia unlawfully and we have not previously had the opportunity to check their identity and assess their claims. On that point, I note that on 21 June this year in an adjournment debate Senator McKiernan from Western Australia said:

quote.para: Recently there was a demonstration around Australian capital cities where banners were flown that said, `Free the refugees'. I agree with that; I support that. I do not believe any refugee should be detained in this country. But just as I do not believe a refugee should be detained, I do not believe that anybody who arrives unlawfully on our shores and who claims refugee status is automatically a refugee. Many of them are refused, and I think that something like 1,000 people have had their claims for protection refused and are now awaiting removal from Australia.

In my capacity as chair of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, I have had many opportunities to look at individual cases through the course of our inquiries. I want to draw reference to one particular applicant for refugee status who was the focus of an inquiry, among other things, of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee and whose case was featured in a report of the committee called A sanctuary under review: an examination of Australia's refugee and humanitarian determination processes, which was tabled at about this time last year.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: There is a full chapter, chapter 7, that deals with Mr SE's case, and there is a chronology of events dealing with Mr SE at appendix 6. We called him Mr SE because he was an applicant for protection and we were respecting his privacy.

He is not an applicant any longer, but it is interesting to read how Mr SE took in the Australian community, and not only the Australian community but the Australian judiciaryâadvocates on behalf of the individualâby lying through his teeth throughout the process as to who he was. We can talk about that because the Legal and Constitutional Committee actually went into the detention centre, talked to the person in question, took evidence from him and accepted the lies we were told, with his advocate present. Mr Sadiq Elmi arrived in this country in 1997 and made an application for protection that was refused. His appeal to the RRT was refused. I think he made about five or six requests to the minister to exercise his discretion, which were all refused. He was about to be removed from Australia when he convinced the pilot of the aircraft taking him out of Melbourne that he should not be removed. He then made application to the High Court of Australia. His advocates went off to the United Nations. The United Nations Commissioner for Human Rights requested non-removal from Australia and the person was taken off an aircraft out of Perth. The minister allowed Sadiq Elmi to make a second application for refugee status. When, under the natural justice provisions of application for protection in Australia, Mr Sadiq Elmi was shown that the department knew he was not who he said he was and that, therefore, he was not entitled to refugee status, he withdrew his application and made arrangements to go somewhere else. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to take up in more detail one of the issues I raised in my speech on the budget last week, namely aged care. The government has shown itself to be completely negligent in the area of aged care. There are three things that have come to light in the last week, for which the government must be held accountableâor, more particularly, for which the Minister for Aged Care must be held accountable. Firstly, it was revealed last week that the federal government has underfunded aged care to the tune of $1.3 billion in the next four years. Previously, the government has seen aged care budgets increase by an average of nine per cent per year over the last four years. So why does the government suddenly think it is satisfactory for it to budget for an average of just four per cent per year increase in the next three years? With an ageing population and the required improvements in facilities and standards of care, it is ludicrous for the government to believe that it will need less money to tackle the growing problem. The $1.3 billion shortfall between what it has budgeted for and what will be required shows once again the complete lack of commitment by this government to meet the needs of our older and frail population, and no $300 bribes or government advertising can change that.

speech.para: The second example in the past week of the government's inability to handle this area has been the appointment of another Minister Bishop mate to the so-called independent Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency. The appointment of long-time friend Mr. Harrowell to chair the board of the accreditation agency smacks of another attempt to muzzle the body that is supposed to conduct the accreditation system which regulates the aged care system. This appointment comes on top of the reappointment of Ms Bishop's own campaign manager to the board of the agency. These two incidents raise serious questions about the independence of the agency from government pressure. Significantly, both peak aged care organisations and the two largest aged care providersâCatholic Health Australia and Uniting Care Australiaâhave also stepped into the debate, calling for an inquiry to look at the lack of transparency of the government's agency.

The third aged care problem which we highlighted last week was the ongoing saga of the Yagoona Nursing Home. Nine weeks ago, the government received a shocking report from the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency on the Yagoona Nursing Home. That report found that the nursing home failed all four care standards, with two being rated as `critical', and effectively recommended that the nursing home be closed down. The agency's report on Yagoona revealed that residents suffered temperatures of 48 degrees in summer, cold showers, the use of unauthorised restraints, a high rate of falls and a potential disaster in the event of a fire. In addition to this, the tragic death of former Yagoona patient Mrs Thomas has been revealed, coupled with the minister's failure to address the complaint from Mrs Thomas's son after his mother's passing.

The government chose to ignore the recommendation from the standards agency and its own accreditation guidelines by allowing the Yagoona Nursing Home to continue to operate. Not only has the government allowed the nursing home to remain open; it failed to impose any of the sanctions it has available under the Aged Care Act. In question time, Labor revealed that the government reversed the decision to close down the Yagoona Nursing Home, which happens to be run by a company that has contributed $14,000 to the Liberal Party. We have heard that the nursing home believed that the agency would do nothing because the owner `knew people'. That obviously refers to the owner's link with the Liberal Party and the $14,000 donation to their coffers. This is no way to run a monitoring system. People must be assured that the nursing homes they place their loved ones into will be investigated without fear or favour. Sadly, in the case of Yagoona, it appears that this has not happened, and Labor will pursue the murky nature of the government's handling of the dreadful allegations surrounding this nursing home.

As I said in the Main Committee last week, I cannot understand how the federal government could have framed a budget that was supposed to be full of goodies for older people yet neglected something as fundamental as aged care. The budget produced a $71 million cut from care subsidies that comes on top of the $90 million cut in 1999. The only additional money announced was $13.8 million for standards, monitoring and complaints resolution, which is an ineffective attempt to tackle the symptoms of declining care standards, and a $2 million aged care communication or spin doctoring strategy. Yet there was not one single extra bed in this budget. This is despite the fact that as at 30 June 2000 there was a national shortage of 10,500 aged care beds.

The most critical shortage of beds is in my home state of Victoria, where a shortfall of 4,480 beds has been revealed by the government's own targets. As a result, waiting times for aged care in Victoria continue to grow. In 1997-98 just five per cent of Victorians assessed as needing nursing home care had to wait more than three months to find a bed. By 2000 that had grown to 20 per cent. It is intolerable that one in five Victorians needing nursing home care are forced to wait more than three months for a bed. This puts immense pressure on families and on Victoria's public hospital system.

In my electorate of Chisholm there is a brand-new facility in Ashwood run by the Cabrini health group. They have already bought licences for 30 high-care places, and those are in operation. With that in mind, Cabrini bought a site and built a wonderful new facility that has 90 bedsâ30 for the high-care licence they had, and 60 which have been able to get no licence as a low-care facility. Anyone from Melbourne would be aware that Cabrini run a hospital in Malvern that has a fantastic reputation, and that they have a very distinguished history of delivering quality health care services. Despite this, the government has not granted Cabrini the 60 bed licences they need. Consequently these beds lie idle, while older people wait in hospitals, desperate for a nursing home bed.

I had the pleasure of actually opening Cabrini Nursing Home very recently, and it was like an episode of Yes, Minister, walking around looking at this beautiful, state-of-the-art facility but with empty beds and no patients. I condemn the government for not providing to Cabrini Nursing Home the licences that are so desperately needed. The only conclusion I can draw is that the Cabrini Nursing Home has fallen victim to either government incompetence or penny-pinching in its failure to provide the bed licences the facility needs to start caring for residents. The minister dodges the whole issue of bed shortages by counting in her bed figures aged care beds which have been allocated but which are not built or operating. These are the `phantom beds'. They exist only in the imagination of Minister Bishop. To further illustrate the point, in the 1999 round Minister Bishop allocated 140 beds to an aged care provider to build in the Mornington Peninsula. The provider has had two years to get the beds operational, yet the building has not even started. What sort of crazy system do we have where 140 bed licences are handed out for beds not even built while I have 60 new beds lying idle in Cabrini at Ashwood? This just does not make sense.

Lastly, I would like to draw the attention of the House to the dire shortage of nursing staff available to nursing homes in Victoria. Last Friday a gentleman came to visit me who lives in my electorate and runs a nursing home in Blackburn. He and his wife, a highly trained nurse, have been running this facility for the past five years. Last week, one of their sisters rang in ill to the nursing home. They have been blessed with a stable and caring staff and have had to rely on agency staff to fill only three vacancies in the past five years, but last week they had a need, because the accredited nurse on the shift was ill. They called 12 agencies and could not get a replacement for the shift. Some of the agencies even laughed and said that they must be joking if they thought they would find a qualified nurse to do a night shift in a nursing home. Other nursing homes rung by my constituent also spoke of the enormous difficulty in getting and keeping trained staff in nursing homes. Why would you work there, they asked, when you can earn more and do less work in a video store. This man is now faced with the prospect of having to break guidelines in order just to stay operational or else to ask his wife to work double or triple shifts to stay in business. It is a terrible situation.

This is a problem that is particularly acute in Victoria where, under the Kennett government, around 2,000 nurses were cut from the system, leading to a staffing crisis and bed shortages. To its credit, the new Victorian government has begun a campaign to recruit 1,300 nurses from the pool of nurses in Victoria who have left the profession. Figures recently showed that 662 nurses signed up for free refresher and re-entry courses that they once had to pay for themselves. The Victorian Health Minister, John Thwaites, has said there is a serious shortage of critical care nurses across Australia. To help address this specialist shortage, the Bracks government will fund 201 scholarships this year, including 35 in rural Victoria. These initiatives will go some way to alleviating the problems faced by my constituent.

This is not an issue we can afford to ignore, as the ageing population will see an increased demand for aged care nurses. It is yet another problem the minister has failed to provide leadership on. My constituent also expressed concern at the cost of implementing accreditation at his nursing home. Whilst he believed that accreditation was needed in the industry he asked why it had to be so labour intensive, why it had to cost so much and why it had to take qualified nursing staff away from their primary duty of caring for residents in order to fill in paperwork.

In conclusion, the past week has proven that this government is not responsible enough to handle the complex issues of the aged care system. I look forward to the installation of the aged care plan announced by my leader in February that will see the following: a national benchmark of care, minimum staffing guidelines, more surprise inspections, a new aged care ombusdman, and tougher penalties for substandard nursing homes. Only when we have a Beazley Labor government will families in Australia be able to have any confidence in the monitoring, care and funding levels of this critical area.

In the time remaining, I would like to place on record my sympathies to the family of Roy Longmore, who died last week at the ripe age of 107. I have had the immense pleasure of sharing with Roy and his family his 104th, 105th and 106th birthdays. Roy, as one of our last Gallipoli veterans, was a true symbol of what all Australians hold dearâthe notions of mateship, a fair go for all, courage and a no-nonsense approach to life. Roy had lived for many years at the Elizabeth Gardens Hostel in Burwood in my seat of Chisholm, and to the staff and residents who have lost a friend and character, I send my sympathies. Roy presented to every meal at the hostel in his suit and tie and was constantly saying that he and those who served in World War I were not heroes but were just doing the job that they were told to do. Roy suffered serious injuries in France and was on the verge of losing his legs. Thankfully, this did not happen and following his return to Australia he married, had one son, Eric, and ran a successful business. I congratulate the state government on its decision to honour this true hero with a state funeral. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI was interested that the member for Sturt raised an interesting idea with regard to the Murray-Darling Basin. Whether his aspirations will ever be achieved is worthy of debate. I also would like to talk about a very important part of the Murray-Darling Basin, in particular a project associated with it that goes a long way towards meeting some of the serious salinity and water waste management issues that the member for Sturt raised. In particular, I refer to the Wimmera-Mallee stock and domestic water supply system. It is a good time, in the Centenary of Federation, to talk about this project and recognise the achievements of our pioneers over the past 100 years. There is very little doubt that, without this unique scheme, the arid regions of the Wimmera and the Mallee in the north-west of Victoria would never have been developed and never have grown into the granary of the nation. It is that important resource needed for stock and for domestic familiesâwater.

speech.para: Apart from one small area, this project is completely contained in the federal division of Mallee. A small portion is associated with the western edge of the member for Murray's electorate, but virtually 98 per cent of it is contained within one federal division. It has been a challenge since its construction commenced in the 1890s, when horsedrawn scrapers struggled to excavate a channel system that ultimately ended up as 16,000 kilometres of network channel and became one of the largest open channel water supply systems in the world. It was quite an engineering feat for its time. Its construction continued through the turn of the century, right up to the 1940s, and in fact really continued with the construction of the last remaining storage at Rocklands in the mid-1960s.

Since that time there has been a raging debate because of evidence of salinisation associated with the channel system, the excessive wastage of water and the need to have this scheme piped. It is a debate that has gone on since the sixties, and it was not until the early eighties that we finally got a commitment from the then Fraser government that at least the northern end, the Mallee end, of this scheme would be piped. It was very unfortunate that, with the advent of the Hawke Labor government, the commitment to piping in northern Mallee was abandoned. But we struggled on as a community and, recognising the very important need of this scheme and the preciousness of water, in 1993 the construction was commenced with bipartisan commitment from the coalition government in Victoria and the Labor government here in Canberra.

The northern Mallee is roughly one third of the geographic area of the total scheme, which comprises 2.9 million hectaresâabout 20 per cent of the state of Victoriaâand 16,000 kilometres of open channel for the whole system. After seven years we are just finally finishing about one quarter of it. That means there are three quarters of it yet to go, which is the challenge that I would like to speak about a little later.

Just to give you some idea of this unique scheme, with storages in the southern end associated with the Grampian Mountains, it takes water, as the crow flies, about 350 kilometres in a channel system that reaches the Murray River. There is not a lot of logic in that, but that is the lie of the land for a gravity supply system. Storage capacity is about 450,000 megalitres of water, but the tragedy has been that, each year since the 1960s, we have been wasting 140,000 megalitres of water. That is an enormous amount of waterâthat is, 140 gigalitres of water. It is a volume of water that is hard to imagine. Virtually 60 per cent of the water stored is wasted through seepage into very sandy Wimmera and Mallee soils and through evaporation. Land-holders complain of salinity of water of 3,000 ECs arriving at their properties; it is almost beyond drinking and it is certainly creating problems with supply to stock.

It is a great tribute that now in 2001 we are discussing the funding for the last stage of the northern Malleeâstage 7. Stage 6, associated with the northern and eastern areas of the township of Ouyen, which is right at the top end of the supply scheme, is virtually complete. Now the challenge is to marshal the political courage to tackle the piping of the rest of the Wimmera-Mallee stock and domestic system. The northern Mallee project that has been piped so far saves about 50,000 megalitres per year of about 140,000 megalitres. There is still a lot of water to save.

Last year the Commonwealth, the states, local land-holders, municipalities and catchment management authorities funded a study to determine what the remainder of the scheme would look like, how much water it could save and how we could achieve the construction of the rest of the Wimmera-Mallee stock and domestic system. It is so big that you just cannot think about it being done in one year. It has taken seven years to do seven stages. The rest of the construction will take at least a decade, probably more. The Commonwealth funded the implementation study to the tune of $110,000, funded through a rural partnership program. When you ask the communities down in the Wimmera-Mallee what the issue is that constrains their economic development, you will always get the answer that it is to do with water and the better use of it. The Victorian government responded with funding of $130,000. Wimmera Mallee Water, which is the state instrumentality responsible for this scheme, funded $126,000. Powercorp, the electricity supply company, recognising the benefits for them of a much better coordinated system, contributed $11,000. Local councils and catchment management authorities contributed up to a net amount of $400,000 to conduct the study.

After extensive consultation through the community, it is now ready for its public airing. I am looking forward to facilitating the provision of that report to Canberra and to those responsible to ensure that the momentum that we have gained now in the piping of the scheme can continue. The last two years confirm the very need as to why we should do this. The Grampians water storage, sadly due to lack of rain, is now down to 12 per cent of its capacity. In fact, the Wimmera-Mallee water authority has to pump from below low water level in some of the storages just to get a supply. We have a water supply crisis in the Wimmera, which highlights the point that, as a nation, we can no longer continue to waste the most precious commodity that an arid nation like Australia has.

The member for Sturt has it right there, but I do not think it is a question of laying blame. At the time of its construction, the Wimmera-Mallee stock and domestic system was hailed as an engineering achievement, something of its time. It has been part of the contribution to the development of an important region, the north-west of Victoria. In hindsight, we can look back after 100 years and say, `We could have done it better.' But the advent of new technology, better science, better pumping systems, much cheaper construction for pipes and so forth and better materials provide us with an enormous opportunity now to continue the momentum.

I will be looking forward to an opportunity to present a further case. Members in this place have heard me speak about this pet project of mine for many yearsâI suppose it is because of my engineering backgroundâbut there are just so many examples around the nation where we have got inappropriate water supply schemes such as this. The Wimmera-Mallee scheme provides a good model for other regions to follow so that, as a nation, we can look forward to another century with better use of water. So I support the member for Sturt's contention, but I am a little at odds with him on how to achieve that. We are in partnership as a nation with states, local authorities and local communities, who are far better placed to make their own decisions about what is best for them. One thing is very clear. The message I hear constantly in the Wimmera-Mallee is about the need to make much better use of resources and for the Commonwealth to fund projects of national importance from which the nation can benefit as a whole.
