Bill (on motion by Ms Worth) read a third time.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)â Order! It being approximately 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âIn May 1999 the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs published its SES Simulation Project: Validation Report. It was intended to show that the SES rating of schools was a reflection of relative need. The document stated:

quote.para: Schools with low SES scores have the highest number of School Card recipients and the number of recipients declines as the SES score of the school increases. For example, 33 schools (17% of schools) had SES scores less than or equal to 90. At these schools 40% of students were School Card holders. At the other end of the SES score range, 13 schools (7%) had SES scores greater than 115 and only 4% of students in receipt of assistance under school card.

speech.para: While on average the formula appears to work, it is not an accurate reflection of need. The reason for that is that it uses to approximate need not the resources of the school or the income of the parent but the income of the parent's neighbours. It does this by reference to the average socioeconomic circumstances of the census collection district from where each student comes.

A good example of how the formula can fail is the Sunrise Christian School. It is an R to 7 coeducational primary school with about 600 students located on three campuses of about 200 students each. The school was established by the Adelaide Christian Centre to serve the community and make Christian education available to all. It has a means-tested fee structureâranging from $130 to $510 per termâwhich allows it to take a large proportion of students whose parents are eligible for a health care card or school card. The school has 61 per cent of families earning $30,000 a year or less, while only eight per cent earn $50,000 a year or more.

The school's three campuses are located quite some distance apart. The first is in my electorate of Kingston at Morphett Vale. As an indicator of the relatively low incomes of many of its families, 47 per cent are eligible for a school card or a health care card. It has an SES rating of 97. The second is on the other side of town in the electorate of the member for Sturt. Forty per cent of its families have a school or health care card and it has an SES rating of 98. The third is at Fullarton in the electorate of Adelaide. That is a relatively affluent area, but not all people in an affluent area are affluent. Thirty-seven per cent of the parents of children at the Fullarton campus are eligible for a school or health care card. However, because of the relative affluence of the people in that area, this school in Fullartonâwith 37 per cent of the parents eligible for a health care cardâhas an SES rating of 114. By way of comparison, St Peter's College, which is without doubt the wealthiest category 1 private school in South Australia, has an SES rating of 116â only two points higher. Under the government's funding formula, St Peter's gets a funding increase but the Sunrise Christian School gets nothing. When the three Sunrise campuses are combined, they have an average school or health card rate of 41 per cent and an SES rating of 103.

The consequence is that the Sunrise School will struggle to provide the facilities and programs that will make it attractive to parents who will know that those facilities and programs are available in another low fee Christian school not too far away. The school will have two choices. The first is that they may gradually lose those students in the higher fee paying bracket, bearing in mind that the fees are means-tested, because the parents will realise that there are better facilities and programs available at other schools for the same level of fees they are paying at Sunrise. Those other schools are receiving increases over the quadrennium of between $232 and $1,478 per student. The second choice would be to put up the fees at Sunrise, effectively excluding the children of the parents on low incomesâthose whom the school was established to cater for. If the funding formula were truly needs based, the school would be able to continue providing a Christian education to children from low income families. If choice and access are important objectives of the SES funding formula, as the minister says when he is defending it in parliament, then the formula has failed the Sunrise School. The SES ratings for the Morphett Vale and Paradise campuses more accurately reflect the needs of the families from those areas using the school, but the rating for the Fullarton campus does not, and that will affect the whole school. I am seeking a meeting with the minister to discuss the SES formula with him.

talk.start.para: â Last week the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade handed down its report on visits to immigration detention centres in Australia. Having had an interest and a responsibility in this area for a number of years, I decided to read the report and follow through on some of the details. I inform the House that I was extremely disappointed with the quality of the report. There were many untested and subjective assertions in the report, assertions that were completely untested anywhere against departmental or other evidence. My first impression was one of disappointment at the failure of the committee to pursue the task that it was given by the Senate and the House of Representatives.

speech.para: I have known the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. Philip Ruddock, for many years, even before entering this parliament, and I have found him to have been an extremely honourable and compassionate man. He is one of the founders of the parliamentary branch of Amnesty International. It is an organisation which I have not belonged to because I have not always agreed with some of the attitudes of Amnesty. Philip Ruddock has been assiduous in his stand for human rights around the world and he has been an example to many of us in his commitment. In the administration of his portfolio, I have found him to have been consistent with those ideals, compassionate, thoughtful and always caring for the needs of those that are within his responsibility.

I have no trouble in coming into this House and supporting my colleague and expressing my disappointment at this report. I only have to look at some of the remarks made in the Senate by Senator McKiernan, who was also a member of that committee. Senator McKiernan has been committed to the wellbeing of migrants and has taken, at his own expense, the initiative of travelling around the world to visit detention centres and to look at the problems of refugees. Senator McKiernan commented about members of the committee that, in his observation:

quote.para: ... although they are speaking as if they are experts on detention centres, many of them did not actually visit the detention centres.

speech.para: They produced a report without that valuable experience. He goes on to say that his great problem with this is that what the detainees said has not been tested. He mentions examples of drug abuse, claims that there were drugs available in the detention centres and also untested comments that are obvious through the report, such as those that appear at in paragraph 4.20 on page 34:

quote.para: It was alleged that 60 points per week were given at Woomera for cleaning toilets and 90 points for working in the kitchen, while Curtin only gave 28 and 24 respectively.

speech.para: I do not know what that is supposed to mean. I do not know why you would put that in a report unless it was of some real merit or value. I also refer the House to the report to the parliament of Australia by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Not the Hilton. There is also a report from the Ombudsman available to the parliament. The Ombudsman said that he believed that security ought to be tightened. So when my colleagues visit detention centres and they see barbed wire they are surprised! That was a report to this parliament by the Ombudsman, saying that security was not good and needed to be changed. All in all, I believe that the attitudes of the Labor Party in particular are absolutely hypocritical in this area. The shadow minister, Mr Con Sciacca, says:

quote.para: A future Labor Government would under no circumstances grant a general amnesty to illegal immigrants.

speech.para: And:

quote.para: Laborâ

speech.para: he saysâ

quote.para: will be as tough, if not tougher than the present Government on illegal immigrants.

speech.para: However, in practice one sees in the House on a day-to-day basis an unwillingness by the shadow minister to lead his party to a point where they will enter into pure and proper bipartisanship on these difficult issues. Nobody wants to see people coming ad hoc, willy-nilly, into Australia and no action taken against them. However, it is a responsibility of the shadow minister to do more than obstruct here and in the Senate those measures that a compassionate, thoughtful minister wants to introduce to both make life better for the refugees and also process their cases more quickly. It is my personal view that anyone coming here without papers ought to be deported. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise in this adjournment debate to inform the House of a tragic series of events that took place over a year and a half ago. On 1 October 1999 an incident occurred at a private residence resulting in an occupant of the house, Mr John Wason, shooting four police officers and shooting at several other police as they carried out a rescue. At 7.35 p.m. ambulance services received a call from Mr Wason requesting an ambulance for his father, whom he said had suffered a heart attack. Two ambulance officers responded to the call. Mr Wason's father was taken to hospital. The ambulance officers then notified the police, as it was obvious he had been seriously assaulted, rather than suffered a heart attack as originally reported. Mr Wason Sr died from these injuries a few days later.

speech.para: At 8 p.m. Sergeant Commadeur and three other police officers attended and unsuccessfully attempted to establish communications with Mr Wason, who had locked himself inside the house. At 9.35 p.m. Mr Wason appeared on the front veranda. Senior Constable Eames, a fully trained negotiator, moved to the fence line to question him and was then shot in the chest. He was shot again as he crawled to a safer position. Police officers were fired upon from close range as they tried to rescue the wounded officer. Detective Miller, attempting to stop traffic and pedestrians, was shot in the stomach and then rolled into a ditch beside the highway. Officer Commaduer and Superintendent Mansell, despite being under fire, dragged Senior Constable Eames to a safer position. Superintendent Mansell sustained injuries to his back during this rescue operation.

Streets were cordoned off, and ambulances began to arrive but could not get to the seriously wounded officers due to constant rifle fire. Superintendent Mansell arranged for an armoured vehicle to retrieve Detective Miller, who was seriously wounded and still under fire. An off-duty nurse, Mary-Anne Beckmans, and two officers had reached Detective Miller and were comforting him, despite being vulnerable targets themselves. Inspector Kaminski, who was east of the house, was also shot and seriously wounded, as was as Sergeant Lakaitis, who was with him. In fact, Sergeant Lakaitis, who was wearing a bulletproof vest, had placed his body over his seriously wounded colleague to protect him and was shot in the lower leg as a result.

Police officers kept Mr Wason inside his house while Superintendent Mansell removed Senior Constable Eames, who by then was in a critical condition, and transported him to hospital. The police officers had been pinned down by gunfire for an hour, and some of the wounded officers were close to death. At around midnight Special Operations Group officers arrived and, along with a relieving operations commander, set up a command post in a nearby street. The Special Operations Group eventually entered the house the next day where Mr Wason was found, having reportedly died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

Honourable members could be forgiven for thinking that this series of events took place in Northern Ireland, in the Middle East or even in an Australian capital city. This happened in the normally peaceful community of Kangaroo Flat, approximately four kilometres from central Bendigo. Two senseless fatalities and four seriously wounded or injured police officers were the horrible consequences of this tragedy. I am pleased to inform the House that the injured officers are making good progress in recovering from their physical injuries.

I raise this matter tonight because a coroner's inquiry into aspects of this incident was scheduled to conclude in Bendigo today. Hopefully, this will explain the circumstances surrounding these tragic events. This incident again demonstrates the considerable danger that police and other emergency service personnel all too often confront in the course of their duties. The officers were called to what might have been expected to be a routine domestic situation, something that is a regular occurrence in the normal daily duties of policemen and policewomen throughout our cities and towns.

I know that all honourable members from both sides of this House will join with me and the central Victorian community in expressing our sincere appreciation for the way these officers and those civilians who assisted carried out their duties, at considerable personal risk to themselves. The people of Bendigo can take great comfort in knowing that we have police officers and civilians who are prepared to put their own lives at risk to protect not only their colleagues but the general public they serve so competently.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Women's Task Force on Violence

talk.start.para: âLast week in parliament I raised the report of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Women's Task Force on Violence, otherwise known as the Robertson report, after its chair, Queensland academic Boni Robertson. I publicly thank Mark Metherell of the Sydney Morning Herald for his willingness to write the story which helped bring the dark horror of this report to the full attention of Australia so that we can together fully address the issues that it raises.

speech.para: Also, I was recently given a copy of an article from the Herald Sun of 2 March 2000 by Andrew Bolt which is highly relevant to the current debate on this national tragedy. As a matter of fact, last week in my speech I asked Mr Clark what he had done to respond to the Robertson report. I thought at the time that I was the first to put the question to him, but it seems that Andrew Bolt had beaten me to it. His article was entitled `Forget Geneva grandstanding, Mr Clark. There's a crisis at home'. I will quote it verbatim for the Hansard. It said:

para.inline: I saw this girl who came in, cuffed in police custody. She was only 14 years old. She was charged with shop-lifting in town. Her mother was called and through the discussion disclosed that she was concerned her daughter had the pox.
She was brought inside the Sexual Health Service for checkup ... I have never seen a girl so red raw inside. She screamed all the way through the consultation.
Turns out she had been sexually assaulted since the age of three. (She) was the first person I have ever seen where I thought, âThere is no hope for you.â

speech.para: This was from a witness to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Women's Task Force on Violence. The article continues:

quote.para: Geoff Clark, I beg you. Be the Aboriginal leader your people are crying out for.
Call off your trip next week to Geneva, where you plan to try to embarrass Australia over mandatory sentencing.
Sure, many radicals want you, as head of ATSIC, our top Aboriginal body, to make fine speeches to the United Nations.
And ATSIC won't begrudge you the thousands of dollars for your trip. Hell, noâit's got $12 million a year to splash on travel and Swiss hotels.
But, Geoff, there is a far more urgent battle for you to fight.

Cancel Geneva. Mark your chairmanship of ATSIC by instead publicly going out bush to force everyoneââseriousâ journalists and black leaders in particularâfinally to confront what they have ruthlessly ignored: the terrifying self-destruction of Aboriginal communities.
Force them to accept that apologies, blame throwing, Olympic boycotts and teary speechesâ whether in Canberra or Genevaâwon't come close to ending this misery.
That misery has now been exposed with brutal honesty by a task force of 15 Aboriginal women, led by Associate Professor Boni Robertson of Griffith University.

Those 50 women travelled Queensland, the state with the most Aborigines, listening to their people talk of the mayhem engulfing them. Page after page of their report to the Queensland Government describes scenes of a nightmare. Scenes like the one at the top of this article.

Or like this one: A three-year-old child in (one) community was sexually assaulted by three males and about 10 days later another male returned, and after sexually assaulting her, assaulted her again using a mangrove root.

Or: A 10-year-old had been caring for his siblings, a one- and two-year-old, for three weeks after being abandoned by their mother. They were reported to have no money or food, and the 10-year-old was apprehended stealing food in a supermarket.
The report tells of children being punched, kicked, neglected, abandoned, raped or left so hungry by drinking parents that they sniff petrol to dull the pangs.
It tells of elders bashed by their grandsons for cash for booze or drugs. Of drunken men and horrific attacks on women, and of local nurses being often frightened to help.

It sums up: âAppalling acts of physical brutality and sexual violence are being perpetrated within some families and across communities to a degree before unknown in indigenous life. Murders, bashings and rapes, including sexual violence against children, have reached epidemic proportions.â
Recently a sad Aboriginal boy hanged himself in a Darwin jail. The media and rights activists have been in uproar since over our âracismâ.
Well, the Robertson task force found one Aboriginal town in which 17 youngsters killed themselves in a single year, three children died of neglect, and at least two males were murdered.
Where was the anger then? The speeches in Geneva? The protests?
âSomething has gone desperately wrong,â the Robertson report says in anguish.
Many great social âreformsââfrom equal pay for stockmen and the right to alcohol, to land rightsâhave done too little good or much harm.
Blame racism all you like, but the report says many Aborigines in fact blame the âAboriginal industryâ for now wasting much of the $2.1 billion we spend each year on Aboriginal programs.
Spot on. ATSIC spends $12 million a year just on conferences, and a staggering $15 million on public affairs, communications and publications.
But until last year, it spent barely a cent in three years to curb the family violence so starkly described by Boni Robertson's team. Even now it can find just $1 million for it. What a disgrace.

The women behind this report won't admit outright the Aboriginal future must lie in integration. But they insist: âIf a program, activity or policy has no impact on the ground, do not bother with it.â
That describes Geoff Clark's trip to Geneva perfectly.
Stay home, Geoff. You have real work to do right here.

talk.start.para: âI would like to turn my comments this evening to infrastructure. The Treasurer's budget speech mentioned the Scoresby Freeway in outer Melbourne, no doubt a much needed piece of infrastructure for that part of Australia, for which $220 million has already been announced and which is to be toll free. The budget papers also contain the $41 million first instalment on the Western Sydney Orbital, which will have two or three tolls. This 39-kilometre stretch of the orbital will form a vital section of the 18,500 kilometre national highway system, yet it will be the only section that will attract a toll.

speech.para: Presently the motorists of Western Sydney who use the M2 to travel to work are charged $3.30 each way or a total of $33.30 for the full week. If you add to this the new Western Sydney Orbital toll of a further $5 or whatever the going rate is at the time, people will be paying a weekly toll well in excess of $80. That is, of course, without coming off the M2 and using the bridge or the tunnel or the Eastern Distributor, which all attract a toll.

There has been strong community and local opposition to the decision of the federal government to impose a toll on the Western Sydney Orbital. The orbital is a major piece of transport infrastructure for Western Sydney that will join the South Western Sydney Freeway at Liverpool to the Pacific Highway in Sydney's north. The orbital will run through the Labor held electorates of Greenway, Chifley, Prospect, Fowler and Werriwa. The member for Fowler has suggested a cash-back scheme for locals, saying in a press release:

quote.para: ... otherwise they would be forced to avoid it and add to congestion on the local road systems.

speech.para: And, further:

quote.para: Someone travelling each day from Hinchinbrook to Blacktown could face a $50 a week toll collection just to get to work.

speech.para: The point is that many local people who will use the orbital are battling parents who have a large mortgage and who are having to cope with the higher cost of living caused by the GST. It is outrageous that this federal government will force these people to pay an extra $50-plus per week for using the orbital to get to work.

A recent report from the National Audit Office indicates that approximately $2.9 billion raised through the imposition of a road user levy built into petrol prices has been diverted from the Australian Land Transport Development account into consolidated revenue. The money could be used to construct the orbital without the need for a toll. The CEO of the NRMA said in response to the orbital announcement:

quote.para: Motorists have been burdened with a fuel excise which has seen the federal government achieve a windfall of $470 million in revenue annually. In total the extra 3 cents per litre collected post GST is yielding an extra $960 million in fuel excise annually.
The federal government collects $13 billion annually in fuel excise, but currently returns only $1.5 billion or 11.5% to road funding.

speech.para: In these circumstances, the federal government's argument that it cannot afford to fund such a significant national highway infrastructure project is unjustifiable. Sydney already has four toll roads, three of them feeding the west. We do not need any more.

Large sections of the Pacific Highway, including the Bulahdelah bypass, are being funded by the federal government, and the Prime Minister has recently announced that the federal government will build the $1 billion Scoresby Freeway with joint funding by the federal and state governmentsâboth without the need for a toll. These are examples of the federal government's unfair, politically motivated funding policies.

The Scoresby Freeway is the Victorian equivalent of the Western Sydney Orbital but has the fortune to run through marginal Liberal seats. The Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board is also opposed to the orbital toll. The chair of the planning infrastructure transport committee of the board, Mr Roy Medich, said:

quote.para: The board fully supports construction of the Western Sydney Orbital as the number one infrastructure priority for NSW.

speech.para: He also stated:

quote.para: Evidence continues to mount that a $5 orbital toll is just another example of Western Sydney motorists being financially disadvantaged while other regions are receiving similar essential services for free. The people of Western Sydney are entitled to feel they are not getting a fair go from either the federal or NSW government on this issue.

speech.para: The completion of economic development of Western Sydney is affected by the capacity and efficiency of the existing transport network to service commercial vehicles and freight movements. Greater Western Sydney has a population of 1.6 million people. It has a gross national product of $35 million and produces 10 per cent of the New South Wales agricultural output, yet it has no standard freeway cross-regional road. This orbital is vital for the economic development of Western Sydney, but it should be toll free.

subdebateinfo.title: Kalgoorlie Electorate: Goldfields North Heritage Trail

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to bring the attention of the House to a number of people, always hardworking, in the goldfields community. On this occasion, it is members of the Goldfields Esperance Development Commission Colin Purcell and Alison Roberts, and members of the Goldfields Esperance Area Consultative Committee Ron Yurevich and Felicity Gilbert. Ghost towns and long-abandoned historic mining settlements are among the legacies of the rich and colourful history of the goldfields area. This area includes the vibrant city of Kalgoorlie-Boulder and the mining towns of Laverton, Leonora, Leinster, Menzies and Coolgardie. However, it was once an area crammed with bustling and prosperous mining settlements nestled within a harsh and hostile environment. Life was tough, the people were tough, and their determination and efforts in such conditions can only be admired.

speech.para: An attempt to paint a picture of these intriguing times and to encourage people to explore this bygone era of Australian and goldfields history has recently been supported by a $126,500 federal government grant. Goldfields visitors and locals alike will benefit from the 975-kilometre Goldfields North Heritage Trail, which was given a major boost with Regional Assistance Program funding announced earlier this month. The project is an innovation of the Goldfields Esperance Development Commission and Australia Unlimited Taskforce and is endorsed by the Goldfields Esperance Area Consultative Committee.

The trail will connect the communities of Kalgoorlie--Boulder, Menzies, Kookynie, Leonora, Laverton, Broad Arrow, Ora Banda and Coolgardie. Along the way it will pass through numerous historic mining settlements and ghost towns, including Davyhurst, Mt Morgans, Gwalia, Siberia, Kanowna, Mulwarrie, Yarri, Malcolm and Murrin Murrin. The area impacted by the trail will be some 45,000 square kilometres, about 66 per cent of the size of Tasmania. The idea of this heritage trail is to encourage both exploration of the ghost towns and graveyards from the bygone gold rush days and appreciation of the colourful history of the goldfields area. The trail is designed to be a two- to three-day drive using the existing road network but with several four-wheel drive options to explore off the beaten track. The main trail will be suitable for both self-drive and guided tour visitors. As well as ghost towns and graveyards, the focus will be on examples of spectacular and unique federation architecture and the remarkable and often emotional human history of the area. This concept will make a tremendous contribution both to tourism in the area and to ensuring this history is kept alive in the minds of today's generations.

Too often the stories of the people who were instrumental in shaping this country are forgotten. Another aspect of the heritage trail will be the use of oral histories and audio interpretation to add a unique character to the overall heritage experience. The trail will also have a positive effect on the economies of the small towns along the trail and will help attract new visitors to the region and prolong the stay of existing visitors. Locals with a strong interest in local history also are expected to be heavy users of the trail. The developers of the trail say its creation will provide employment during its development and implementation and an ongoing and sustainable source of revenue through its potential to draw visitors to areas previously untouched by tourism. Concern for the community and regional development by members of development commissions and area consultative committees is to be commended. Without their commitment, many great federal government funding programs would go unnoticed.

talk.start.para: â The announcement last week or the week before that Flight West would discontinue their services into Western Queensland and the gulf country was a very serious blow to the quality of life and essential services throughout those areas. Flight West nominated three causes for their demise. One of those causes was competition. There is absolutely no doubt that the free skies policy and the national competition policy have combined to help in the demise of Flight West. A country so sparsely populated as Australia clearly cannot sustain policies such as national competition policy. National competition policy has proved to be a disastrous failure for all of Australia, I would submit, and most certainly for rural Australia, and it needs to be abolished and replaced by some other form of legislation to avoid the monopoly position held by government utilities, which was the original reason.

speech.para: That brings me to the second topic I wish to raise briefly this evening, which is that the original Hilmer report on transport, which was the forerunner, the harbinger, of the national competition policy document, in fact delineated as the major reason for reform the necessity to overcome the $4,000 million of subsidies pouring into the commuter transportation system of the metropolitan areas of Australia. Not only has that subsidisation not been removed, but now it is estimated to have risen to $6,000 millionâa very hard figure to delineate. I would not doubt, if in the mid-1980s it was $4,000 million, that it would now be $6,000 million.

In sharp contrast, when the people of the electorate of Kennedy go to work in the morning, they have to pay 120 per cent tax on their petrol and the equivalent of about a 30 per cent tax on their motor car in a tariff to protect jobs in the big cities. We are not denying the big cities that benefit. In fact, these days I would be an enthusiastic supporter of the tariff on motor vehicles, but it makes us extremely angry when the sugar industry gets different treatment.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)â Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

para.inline: House adjourned at 11.00 p.m. until Tuesday, 26 June 2001 at 2.30 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

talk.start.para: âto move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) acknowledges that the safety of our children should be a paramount concern for all Governments;
(2) recognises current safety standards imposed on coaches and long-distance buses include the mandatory requirement that these vehicles be fitted with seat belts;
(3) points out the growing evidence, from studies conducted both in Australia and overseas, that the use of seat belts on these vehicles undoubtedly saves lives in the case of accidents;
(4) acknowledges that currently hundreds of thousands of Australian school children travel daily to school on buses that are not fitted with seat belts; and

(5) calls on all State and Territory Governments across the nation to put safety first and move urgently to at least require all new and replacement school buses be fitted with seat belts so this safety issue is eventually and finally addressed.

talk.start.para: âto move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) acknowledges the financial difficulties being experienced by certain sectors of the citrus industry;
(2) recognises in particular those difficulties being experienced by the arid zone regions of southern Australia in the Riverina, Murray Valley and Riverland in particular reference to oranges;
(3) commends orange growers for their willingness to engage in structural reform moving away from valencias for the juice concentrate markets towards markets for fresh fruit;
(4) commends the industry for its huge effort in the export of navel oranges; and
(6) calls for financial and export enhancement assistance to this significant industry in the arid zones of rural Australia.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Nursing Homes and Aged Care Hostels
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1600)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 5 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many (a) church managed and (b) privately owned nursing homes and aged persons' hostels are there in each State and Territory.
(2) How many clients are there in (a) church managed and (b) privately owned nursing homes and aged persons' hostels in each State and Territory.

By operation of subsection 43(2) of the Federal Magistrates Act 1999, the Family Law Rules and the Federal Court Rules apply, to the extent that the Federal Magistrates Rules are insufficient, so far as they are relevant and subject to the direction of the Federal Magistrates Service or a federal magistrate. (10) The Federal Magistrates Service has been established on the basis that it shares the resources of the Federal and Family Court of Australia, where that is practical. (c) No.

The Government has decided to appoint an additional federal magistrate based in either Darwin or Adelaide, who will hear cases regularly in both locations as well as on circuit to regional areas. (12) Yes. $600,000 per annum for 2001-01 and 2001-02. talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question, in accordance with advice provided to me, is as follows:

(3) The rate of interest, if any, is agreed between the resident and the provider and must be no more than the legislated maximum permissible rate.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 May 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister able to say what is the current scientific opinion regarding the danger of electromagnetic radiation emitted from mobile telephone towers.
(2) What federal laws apply to the location of mobile telephone towers.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The weight of scientific opinion is that there is no substantiated evidence of adverse public health effects from exposure to electromagnetic energy (EME) at the levels experienced by the general public. No evidence clearly linking EME emissions from radiocommunications devices, including mobile telephone towers, to adverse health effects was presented to the recent Inquiry by the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee.

As part of the EME research program, funded by a levy on apparatus licences issued under the Radiocommunications Act 1992, the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency has taken detailed measurements of EME levels around a selected number of mobile telephone base stations throughout Australia. These measurements established that mobile telephone base stations produce EME exposures at levels far below relevant public exposure limits as mandated by the Australian Communications Authority in the Radiocommunications (Electromagnetic Radiation - Human Exposure) Standard 1999.

(2) The Telecommunications Act 1997 removed many exemptions that telecommunications carriers previously enjoyed from the provisions of State and Territory planning and environment laws. Under this Act, responsibility for approving the siting of most telecommunications facilities rests with the relevant States and Territory authorities.

However, there are a limited number of exceptions. Schedule 3 of the Act provides immunity from State and Territory laws for telecommunications carriers installing facilities and undertaking activities that fall within the ambit of the Telecommunications (Low Impact Facilities) Determination 1997.
When installing low impact facilities, telecommunications carriers are still required to comply with rules of conduct that are set out in the Act, and in the Telecommunications Code of Practice 1997.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 May 2001:

quote.para: (1) What are the reasons for Senator Helen Coonan being chosen as Chairperson of the Sydney Airport Community Forum.

(2) Has he seen the comments of Senator Coonan, reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 17 May 2001 where the Senator urged members to word some motions better, suggesting that poor use of language was one reason why inadequate responses from the Government may have been given.
(3) Has the poor use of language impeded the satisfactory resolution of aircraft noise problems at Sydney Airport.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Senator Coonan's background and experience will make her an excellent Chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum.

(2) and (3) Clearly the better resolutions passed by the Sydney Airport Community Forum are worded the better they will convey the views of the Forum to the Government. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 4 June 2001:

quote.para: (1) Will the main road known as QANTAS Drive into Sydney Airport become a tollway or a restricted road when the airport is sold.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government wants to ensure that current access arrangements for Qantas Drive continue when the Airport is privatised. The sale arrangements will make it clear that the new operator will not be permitted to impose a toll on the use of Qantas Drive or restrict access.
